questions.text: A patient was diagnosed to have ependymoma arising from the filum terminale region of the spinal cord. MRI revealed the destruction of both sensory and motor roots supplying the bladder. Which of the following would be seen in such a patient's bladder?

choices.text: Initially flaccid and distended bladder becomes shrunken and hypertrophied gradually
Initially shrunken and hypertrophied bladder becomes  flaccid and distended
The bladder just becomes distended, thin walled and hypotonic
The bladder just becomes shrunken and hypertrophied

questions.solution:
In a denervated bladder where both the afferent and efferent fibers cut off, the bladder will initially be distended but later be shrunken and hypertrophied. 

In Deafferentiation, where the sensory fibers of the bladder are cut off, all the reflex contractions of the bladder are abolished and the bladder is distended, thin-walled and hypotonic.

questions.text: The given electron micrograph shows the largest known virus which infects vertebrates. Which of the following diseases is/are caused by the members of this family of virus?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 3, and 4 are correct. Variola, Molluscum contagiosum, and Orf can be caused by Poxvirus which is shown in the electron micrograph.

On electron microscopy, they appear to be brick-shaped or ellipsoid particles measuring about (300–400) × 230 nm. Poxviruses are DNA viruses and their entire multiplication cycle takes place in the cytoplasm of infected cells.

Orf or Contagious pustular dermatitis is caused by Poxvirus (genus Parapoxvirus). Orf is a disease of sheep and goats transmitted to humans by contact. In humans, the disease occurs as a single papulovesicular lesion with a central ulcer, usually on the hand, forearm, or face.

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by Poxvirus (genus Molluscipoxvirus). It manifests as pink pearly wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center (umbilicated), but not associated with inflammation and necrosis.

Variola or smallpox is also caused by a poxvirus ( genus Orthopoxvirus).

Other options:

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is caused by coxsackievirus. It is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs.

Chicken pox caused by Varicella-zoster virus (HHV-3 virus). Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus which causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles)

Molluscum contagiosum manifests as pink pearly wart like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the centre (umbilicated)

Orf or ecthyma contagiosum with a single lesion - small, firm, red or reddish-blue papule which enlarges into a hemorrhagic pustule or bulla.

Hand foot mouth disease is a common infection in young children, affecting the oral cavity and extremities. Vesicles, which may be very painful, develop in the mouth and may ulcerate.Small, tense blisters, with a surrounding rim of erythema, occur on the palms and soles and fade within 3 days

The image depicts the rash of chickenpox, as different stages of the rash can be seen at one time.

Characteristics of rash of chicken pox:

  • Superficial
  • Pleomorphic
  • Centripetal
  • Unilocular
  • Symmetrical
  • Spares palms and soles, affects flexor surfaces and axilla
  • Rapid evolution
  • Dew drop on Rose-petal appearance

questions.text: You are examining a sample of hepatic tissue where you observe these clumped, amorphous eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes. These structures are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Mallory-Denk bodies, are seen in the image above. They are also called alcoholic hyaline  bodies are clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion bodies in ballooned liver cells that are seen in primary biliary cirrhosis, Wilson's disease, and alcoholic liver disease. These are predominantly composed of keratin intermediate filaments (keratin 8 and 18).

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother wants to get her 2-day-old newborn to be screened for hypothyroidism as she had read on the internet that it is a common cause of preventable mental retardation. Which of the following strategies is most commonly followed for the screening process?

choices.text: A fresh blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A fresh blood sample and screen first for T4 levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

questions.solution:
The most commonly followed strategy for newborn screening of congenital hypothyroidism is using a dried blood sample and screening it first for TSH.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Screening of children for congenital hypothyroidism is very important, as early diagnosis and treatment can help in normal intellectual development. Children diagnosed beyond the neonatal period have a poor outcome.

Screening is usually done between day 2 - day 4 postnatally using dried blood samples for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based approach. Although the TSH-based approach is better, it doesn't identify central hypothyroidism, which can be identified by the T4-first approach. But, the T4-based approach misses out on the cases of compensated hypothyroidism.

The incidence of congenital hypothyroidism is 4 times higher in India compared to western countries. Thyroid dysgenesis has emerged as the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India.

Clinical features of hypothyroidism:

Congenital Acquired
Open posterior fontanel Growth retardation
Umbilical hernia Delayed skeletal maturation
Characteristic edematous facies Delayed dental development
Constipation Delayed puberty
Pallor Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy
Hypothermia Enlarged sella
Large tongue Pseudotumor cerebri
Rough dry skin  
Hypotonia  
Large abdomen  

Management is by thyroid replacement soon after the diagnosis. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

questions.text: You are a part of a project which involves the quality improvement of patient care in the hospital. Plan of the project is given below. Which of the following is correct regarding it?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 3 and 5 are correct.

The given project is an example of network analysis. It is a graphical plan of activities/events that has to be completed in order to reach a target/objective. This brings discipline in the planning. 

The pathway which could delay the whole project if it gets delayed is called the Critical pathway, here the longest pathway is (Start--->task B--->task C--->Finish) as it consists of (5+6)11 days, whereas ( just accounts for 2 days and (Start--->task A---> task D---> task E---> Finish) accounts to (7+2+1)10 days.

Although task D is the longest activity, it is not the longest pathway.

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with a cognitive deficit, involuntary hand and finger movements, and muscle incoordination. He was diagnosed with Huntington's chorea. Which brain structure marked in the given image shrinks rapidly in his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Huntington's disease. The caudate nucleus, which is marked "A," shrinks dramatically in Huntington's disease and, if affected, is also a major cause of chorea movements.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in chorea and dementia and which demonstrates anticipation. The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle. Commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decade of life; motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia.

Markings:

A - Caudate nucleus

B - Thalamus

C - Globus pallidus

D - Putamen

The above image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: The given image shows a normal His bundle electrogram. Which of the following options indicates AV nodal conduction time?

choices.text: From wave 1 to start of wave 3
From wave 1 to start of wave 2
From wave 2 to start of wave 4
From wave 2 to start of wave 3

questions.solution:
The AV nodal conduction time corresponds with the AH interval of HBE, which extends from wave 1 (A wave) to the start of wave 2 (H wave).

His bundle electrogram (HBE):

HBE is the record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve.

It shows 3 deflections, as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes transmission through His bundle

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

PA interval

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to the start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches

questions.text: A patient presented with a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint. There are no skin changes or neurological involvement. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei as shown in the image below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint along with the nuclear-free zones between nuclear palisading observed in the given image is suggestive of schwannoma. Verocay bodies are seen in this condition.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that may arise directly from peripheral nerves and exhibit Schwann cell differentiation. They are commonly associated with mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22. This results in the loss of expression of Merlin, the NF2 gene product. 

Schwannomas are simple to excise surgically as they are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are loosely attached to the associated nerve but do not invade it. Grossly, they appear as firm gray masses. 

Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

The symptoms associated with schwannoma arise due to local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures. Surgical removal is curative. If incompletely excised, the schwannomas can recur locally, but a malignant transformation is extremely rare. 

Other options:

Option B: Ferruginous bodies are seen in asbestosis. These are other inorganic particles that are covered by iron-containing substances. This iron is thought to be derived from ferritin within macrophages.

Option C: Miyagawa bodies are elementary, intracytoplasmic microcolonies of Chlamydia trachomatis found in lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option D: Councilman bodies are seen in liver cell damage which consists of hepatic cell degeneration and necrosis, ballooning of cells, and acidophilic degeneration of hepatocytes.

questions.text: A man presents with headache, fever, and neck stiffness for the last 1 month. On examination, the sign shown in the image below is positive. CSF analysis reveals lymphocytic predominance with low glucose levels. A cobweb coagulum is formed when CSF is left standing. What is the therapy of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario of a positive Kernig's sign, as shown in the image, and CSF analysis findings of lymphocytic predominance with low glucose level and cobweb formation suggest tubercular meningitis. The therapy of choice for this patient is isoniazid + rifampin + pyrazinamide+ ethambutol. 

Kernig's sign is elicited with the patient in supine position. The thigh and knee are flexed over the abdomen. The examiner then tries to passively extend the knee joint. There is severe pain during extension due to meningeal irritation.

Tubercular meningitis is a type of subacute meningitis. It is caused due to the hematogenous dissemination of the bacilli into the brain parenchyma. These bacilli form tubercles. The tubercles undergo caseating necrosis and release the tubercular antigens in the subarachnoid space, leading to inflammation of the meninges. They predominantly involve the basal portion of the brain.

Symptoms include headache, neck stiffness, features of cranial nerve palsies such as facial weakness, downward and outward positioning of the eyes, diminished vision, double vision, and hearing loss. Signs include papilledema, Kernig's sign, and Brudzinki's sign of meningeal irritation.

It is treated with fixed-dose combinations of isoniazid (5 mg/kg/d), rifampin (10 mg/kg/d), pyrazinamide (30 mg/kg/d), ethambutol (15 mg/kg/d), and pyridoxine (50 mg/d) for a period of 6 months. It can be extended by 3-6 months in cases of tubercular meningitis. Also, in HIV-negative patients with TB meningitis, dexamethasone (12–16 mg/d) is recommended for 6 weeks. In India, tuberculosis is managed with a fixed-dose combination and daily dosing of medications.

Other options:

Option B: Ceftriaxone + vancomycin is the initial treatment of choice for acute meningitis due to Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Option C: Ampicillin is the treatment of choice for meningitis due to Listeria monocytogenes and is given for at least 3 weeks.

Option D: Liposomal amphotericin B + flucytosine is used for chronic meningitis due to Cryptococcus neoformans (in patients with no immunosuppression).

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child with  Incontinentia pigmenti presented with the following findings. The lesions shown in the below image are usually seen in which stage of Incontinentia pigmenti?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Hyperpigmented skin lesions, which are usually seen in stage 3 of Incontinentia pigmenti

Incontinentia pigmenti is an X-linked dominant disorder with multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males. It presents in females with skin lesions, teeth abnormalities, alopecia, nail dystrophy, and ocular and neurological findings.

The lesions can be described in 4 distinct stages, which are

  • Stage 1 - Erythematous vesicular rash
  • Stage 2 - Verrucous lesions
  • Stage 3 - Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls
  • Stage 4 - Hypopigmented Patches

Management:

  • No specific treatment is available
  • Symptomatic treatment includes standard management of blisters
  • Ophthalmological follow‐up is required for retinal neovascularization monitoring and treatment

questions.text: A 20-year-old female who is on antiepileptics for generalized seizures is eager to discontinue the therapy. She has been seizure-free on medical control for over 2 years, she has no family history of epilepsy. On evaluation, her neurological examination is normal and her EEG is normal as well. She clearly understands the potential risks and benefits of discontinuation. What is your preferable advice in her case?

choices.text: To discontinue the therapy tapering over 3 days
To continue the treatment with anti-epileptic drugs lifelong
To continue the therapy until 5 years of therapy are completed
To reduce the dose of the drug gradually over 2–3 months

questions.solution:
The drug dose should be reduced gradually over 2–3 months in this female.

Anti-epileptic drugs withdrawal can be attempted after a 2-year seizure-free interval in patients with:

  • No family history of epilepsy
  • Single seizure type
  • Normal EEG
  • Normal neurological examination and intelligence
  • Complete medical control of seizures for 1-5 years

Withdrawal is attempted with the above criteria when the patient is motivated to discontinue the medication and clearly understands the potential risks and benefits. It is preferred to reduce the dose of the drug gradually over 2–3 months. 

Recurrences mostly occur during the first 3 months of discontinuing the therapy, therefore the patient is advised not to drive or swim which are potentially dangerous situations.

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid after overnight fasting. Which of the following images indicate the most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa (red color indicates the area of injury)?
questions.solution:
As the patient in this scenario consumed acid (corrosive) after overnight fasting (i.e. on an empty stomach), the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus. 

In case of a food-filled stomach, the pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take is known as Magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach, and this is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place, in corrosive injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with Down's syndrome is brought to the Medicine OPD by his sister who complains that he has been easily confused and forgetful about his daily activities recently. A provisional diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease is made. Which of the following genes is primarily responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
An increased copy number of the APP gene, which codes for the Aβ protein, is seen in Down's Syndrome (trisomy 21) leading to its overexpression, and that overexpression of APP may lead to the elevated levels of Aβ in Down's Syndrome leading to the development of Alzheimer’s disease. 

 

Alzheimer’s disease is associated with mutations in chromosomes 1, 14, 19, and 21.

    • APP gene on chromosome 21Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome): Extra dose of the APP gene on chromosome 21 is the initiating cause of AD in adult Down’s syndrome and results in excess cerebral amyloid production. 
    • Families with early-onset familial AD (FAD) have point mutations in APP.
  • Presenilin-1 (PS-1) is on chromosome 14 and encodes a protein called S182.
    • Presenilin-2 (PS-2) is on chromosome 1 and encodes a protein called STM2.PS-1 is involved in the cleavage of APP at the γ secretase site and mutations in either gene (PS-1 or APP) may disturb γ-secretase cleavage. 
    • Mutations in PS-1 are the most common cause of early-onset FAD (40–70% of all cases).
    • Mutations in PS-1 tend to produce AD with an earlier age of onset (mean onset 45 years) and a shorter, more rapidly progressive course (mean duration 6–7 years) than the disease caused by mutations in PS-2 (mean onset 53 years; duration 11 years).
  • Apo ε gene on chromosome 19: Three alleles: ε2, ε3, and ε4. The Apo ε4 allele confers an increased risk of AD in the general population, including sporadic and late-onset familial forms.

Mutations in the gene encoding copper­zinc superoxide dismutase (SOD1) on chromosome 21 is associated with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS is a progressive disorder in which there is a loss of the upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem. Inheritance is mostly autosomal dominant.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: Mr. X is a 24-year-old muscular male athlete with a BMI of 21 kg/m2 and Ms. Y is a 36-year-old female with a BMI of 28 kg/m2. Both of them are started on the same drug 'D' which is highly lipid-soluble. Which of the following statement is false about the expected pharmacokinetics of the drug administered to them?

choices.text: Ms. Y requires a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Mr. X
Mr X requires a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Ms. Y
The drug 'D' will have a higher volume of distribution in case of Ms. Y
The drug 'D' will have a lower volume of distribution  in case of Mr. X

questions.solution:
The false statement is "Mr. X requires a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Ms. Y."

Lipophilic drugs are more likely to distribute to areas with high-fat content. The volume of distribution is governed by factors such as fat content in the body, body water composition, etc. Hence, the drug will have a higher volume of distribution in Ms. Y. Since the volume of distribution is directly proportional to the loading dose, Ms. Y would require a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Mr. X. 

Loading Dose = (Vol. of Distribution x Desired Steady-state plasma Concentration)/ Bioavailability

When the time to reach a steady state is long, as it is for drugs with long half-lives, it is desirable to administer a loading dose that quickly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the targeted level of concentration.

 The volume of distribution is the proportionality factor that relates the total amount of drug in the body to the concentration. The following formula calculates it: 

Volume of distribution = Amount of drug in the body/Concentration of the drug in blood or plasma

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image below is being performed on a 35-year-old male patient, who presented with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. His barium swallow showed a bird's beak appearance near the gastroesophageal junction. What is the procedure performed on this patient known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of achalasia cardia, and the procedure shown above is called peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM). 

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder caused due to the degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), thereby causing a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.  

The patients present with a triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods, halitosis is present due to the accumulation of food. Patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. at a later stage.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry. The findings are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure. 

The image below shows the bird beak appearance of the esophagus on the barium swallow.

 Management is as follows:

  • Heller's myotomy
  • Partial fundoplication
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is mainly done for type 1 and 2. For type 3, it is done if there is recurrence after surgery. 

    In this procedure, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created; through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and cardia are visualized and divided.

    The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the patient to a 40–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). 

 Other options:

Option A: NOTES - Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery - It helps access the peritoneal cavity or the abdominal cavity through the gastrointestinal tract, without incising the anterior abdominal wall. It is in the experimental stage and is proposed to replace laparoscopic appendicectomy or cholecystectomy. 

Option B: SILS - Single incision laparoscopic surgery - It is also known as 'scarless’ surgery. It has recently been applied in recent times for gallbladder removal or complex biliopancreatic procedures to minimize the invasiveness of the surgery. 

Option D: ROSE -  Restorative obesity surgery endoscopy helps restore the stomach pouch and size of the outlet in patients who have undergone gastric bypass to help them regain back the weight. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Panesophageal pressurization
Type III
(spastic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Spastic contractions
Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization
DCI > 450mmHg
Disorders of peristalsis

Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions.
DCI>450mmHg
Nutcracker’s esophagus Normal IRP

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text: An ophthalmology resident advises you to perform electroretinography(ERG) in a patient who has been diagnosed with early retinitis pigmentosa. Abnormality in which of the following waves of ERG record will be observed by you in this patient?
questions.solution:
Subnormal B wave is seen in electroretinography of a patient diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa.

Electroretinography (ERG) is the record of changes in the resting potential of the eye induced by a flash of light.

  • Waves of normal ERG
    • a-wave: negative wave possibly arising from the rods and cones
    • b-wave: large positive wave which is generated by Muller cells, but represents the activity of the bipolar cells
    • c-wave: positive wave representing the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium

Abnormal ERG response

  • Subnormal b-wave response is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Extinguished response is seen when there is complete failure of rods and cones function e.g., advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, central retinal artery occlusion
  • A negative response indicates gross disturbances of the retinal circulation

Note: Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. In early cases of RP, As rods are affected first there is reduced scotopic responses; and Later photopic responses reduce with progression, and eventually the ERG becomes extinguished.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child has thin extremities and  hepatomegaly. Investigations revealed hypoglycemia, elevated uric acid levels in the blood, and marked lactic acidosis. The blood sample has the following appearance. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia (milky white plasma), hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease (type Ia). It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase.

Signs and symptoms of von Gierke disease are

  • Seizures 
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Milky white plasma - due to very high serum triglyceride levels and cholesterol levels
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Enlarged kidney
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL)
  • Blood uric acid levels >5 mg/dL
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by nasogastric infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch.
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Oral citrate and bicarbonate administration.
  • HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors and fibrates therapy should be started if triglyceride levels are >900 mg/dL, despite dietary therapy.
  • Allopurinol (10 mg/kg/day) should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

questions.text: Exposure to the following bodily fluids pose a significant risk of HIV infection and therefore need post-exposure prophylaxis:
questions.solution:
Bodily fluids that pose a significant risk of HIV infections are breast milk and cerebrospinal fluid. Exposure to sweat, tears, and non-blood stained saliva, do not pose a significant risk.

Exposures that require post-exposure prophylaxis include:

  • Bodily fluids posing a risk of HIV infection are blood, blood-stained saliva, breast-milk, genital secretions and cerebrospinal, amniotic, rectal, peritoneal, synovial, pericardial and pleural fluids.
  • Mucous membrane or parenteral exposure.   

Exposures that do not require post-exposure prophylaxis include:

  • The exposed individual is already HIV positive.
  • The source is established to be HIV negative.
  • Bodily fluids that do not pose a significant risk are tears, non-blood-stained saliva, urine and sweat.

 

 

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

TDF - Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 

3TC - Lamivudine 

FTC - Emtricitabine 

DTG - Dolutegravir 

ATV/r - Atazanavir + ritonavir 

DRV/r - Darunavir + ritonavir 

LPV/r - Lopinavir + ritonavir 

RAL - Raltegravir 

AZT - Zidovudine 

ABC - Abacavir 

 

 

 

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a hard and irregular lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathological appearance of the specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, and the Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Lobular Carcinoma is usually bilateral, multicentric, and presents as hard irregular masses. It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia. It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary.

It is associated with a mutation in the CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance. Desmoplasia is minimal or absent in this type.

They are Luminal-A type and have an excellent prognosis.


Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also poses a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

The image below shows histopathology findings of papillary carcinoma of the breast:


Option C: Medullary carcinoma of the breast shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates, and pushing border.

The image below shows histopathology findings of medullary carcinoma of the breast:


Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In the intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form a signet ring appearance.

The image below shows histopathology findings of colloidal carcinoma of the breast:

questions.text: A college-going student presents to you with the rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. You also noticed the following sign, when the patient was asked to look in a downward gaze. The ophthalmic examination in this patient usually reveals all the following signs except _______
questions.solution:
Haab's striae are not seen in keratoconus.

Haab’s striae are tears and breaks in Descemet's membrane seen in Congenital glaucoma.

Keratoconus is a progressive disorder in which central or paracentral corneal stromal thinning occurs, accompanied by apical protrusion and irregular astigmatism. Vogt's striae are seen in the keratoconus.

Keratoconus presents with the features of rapidly increasing power of the glasses and localised bulging of the lower lid when the patient looks down.

The signs seen in keratoconus:

  • Direct ophthalmoscopy from a distance of half a meter shows a fairly well-delineated oil droplet reflex
  • Fleischer's ring: Iron deposition on the epithelium
  • Munson’s Sign: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on downward gaze (as shown in the image )
  • Scissoring reflex in retinoscopy
  • Vogt’s striae:  Vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A 32-year-old  female has tested positive for Hepatitis E during an epidemic of this disease. She consults you regarding the transmission, complications, and pathogenicity of this virus. Which of the following is correct about Hepatitis E?
questions.solution:
Options 1 and 4 are correct.

  • Hepatitis E virus has fecal-oral or waterborne transmission but no sexual transmission.
  • Fatality due to Hepatitis E is maximum in pregnant women.

 

Hepatitis E virus is an enterically transmitted hepatitis virus. It has the fecal-oral or waterborne transmission.HEV is also known as E-NANB, i.e., enterically transmitted Non-A Non-B (NANB) hepatitis virus It often appears in epidemics; hence, it is also called epidemic NANB.

Hepatitis E virus has low case fatality rate of about 1%. However the case fatality rate goes up to 20–40 % in pregnant women especially in the last trimester of pregnancy.

Fulminant hepatitis is the most feared complication of viral hepatitis and is primarily seen in hepatits B, D, and E. Hepatitis A rarely causes fulminant hepatitis in older adults and in persons with underlying chronic disease. Fulminant hepatitis is hardly seen in hepatitis C.

Cause  Etiological agent
MC cause of viral hepatitis Hep B
MC cause of Acute viral hepatitis in children Hep A
MC cause of Acute viral hepatitis in Adult Hep E
MC cause of viral Hepatitis in Pregnancy Hep B
MC cause of Acute viral Hepatitis in Pregnancy Hep E
MC cause of Viral HCC Hep B
MC Cause of Chronic hepatitis Hep B
MC Cause of Acute Viral hepatitis leading to Chronic hepatitis Hep C 
Maximum risk and max Potential of Chronicity Hep C
MC cause of Carrier State Hep B
MC Viral Cause of Cirrhosis Hep C
MC Cause of Cirrhosis Alcohol
MC cause of Viral Fulminant hepatitis Hep E
Acute viral hepatitis with highest risk leading to Fulminant hepatitis Hep D

 

Other options: 

Acute viral hepatitis with highest risk of leading to fulminant hepatitis is Hepatitis D. However, Most common hepatitis virus causing fulminant hepatitis is Hepatitis E.

It is caused by a ssRNA virus which belongs to Family Hepevirus. .

Frequency of chronic liver disease is less common and seen in immunocompromised hosts only.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with sensory neuropathy. His history is significant for taking an off-the-counter vitamin B6 supplement in large doses. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this vitamin?

choices.text: It causes prostaglandin mediated cutaneous flushing
It is useful in the management of Homocystinuria
Erythrocyte transaminase assay is used for assessing it's nutritional status
It's deficiency plays a role in the development of hormone-dependent cancers

questions.solution:
Excess Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) causes sensory neuropathy as given in the scenario. The incorrect statement regarding vitamin B6 is it causes prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing. Niacin causes prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing.

The B-complex vitamins which cause toxicity:

  • Niacin - it causes prostaglandin mediated cutaneous flushing, fulminant hepatitis (most fatal manifestation), and glucose intolerance
  • Pyridoxine - it causes sensory neuropathy.

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin B6 - Pyridoxine is a cofactor in the synthesis of cystathionine from homocysteine. Classic homocystinuria is due to cystathionine synthase deficiency which leads to elevated homocysteine levels. It promotes oxidative damage, inflammation and endothelial dysfunction. Supplementation of vitamin B6 has been shown to reduce the level of circulating homocysteine. 

Option C: Vitamin B6 status can be assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminase which is activated by pyridoxal phosphate.

Option D: The active form of Vitamin B6 is pyridoxal phosphate and it removes the hormone-receptor complex from DNA binding, terminating the action of the hormones. In vitamin B6 deficiency, there is increased sensitivity to even low concentrations of steroid hormones(estrogen, androgen, cortisol) leading to the development of hormone-dependent cancer ( breast, uterus, and prostate).

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with cancer of the prostate attempted a low lethality method of suicide but was rescued and he survived. It is noted that he has a history of previous attempts as well. He has good family support and yet, he tried to commit suicide with precautions to avoid discovery. Which of the following are the high-risk points in this patient which indicate that he needs admission to the psychiatric ward?
questions.solution:
Options 1 and 5 are correct.

The risk of Suicide or Suicidal Behaviors:

High risk of suicide: Admission generally indicated

  • Precautions were taken to avoid rescue or discovery
  • The patient is male, >45 years of age,
  • Patient is psychotic
  • Persistent intent is present
  • Attempt was violent
  • patient regrets surviving
  • The patient has poor family/ social support
  • Refusal of help is evident

Moderate risk of suicide: Admission may be necessary

  • Past attempts
  • Contributing medical condition (cancer)
  • Psychosis
  • Major psychiatric disorder
  • Limited family and/or social support
  • Lack of an ongoing clinician-patient relationship
  • Need for supervised setting for medications 

Lesser risk: Release from the emergency department with follow-up recommendations may be possible.

  • The method has low lethality
  • The patient has a stable and supportive living situation
  • Suicidality is a reaction to precipitating events (e.g., exam failure, relationship difficulties)
  • The patient is ready to cooperate with recommendations

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.

questions.text: A 13-year-old obese boy with hypothyroidism presents to you with limitations of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The x-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. Identify the true statement concerning the given radiological finding.

choices.text: Negative Trethowan sign is seen  with Klein’s line intersecting the femoral epiphysis
Positive Trethowan sign is seen  with Klein’s line not intersecting the femoral epiphysis
Negative Trethowan sign is seen with Klein’s line not intersecting the femoral epiphysis
Positive Trethowan sign is seen with Klein’s line intersecting the femoral epiphysis

questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the Positive Trethowan sign with Klein’s line not intersecting the femoral epiphysis. 

Trethowan's sign is suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis. But in SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis. This is known as positive Trethowan's sign.

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis:

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, commonly during 11-20 years, due to the weakening of the upper femoral physis.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, hyperparathyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features include limitation of abduction and internal rotation with Tenderness in Scarpa's triangle.

questions.text: Which of the following options are  correct regarding the mode of resistance seen in the Anti-tubercular drugs ?
questions.solution:
Options 3 and 4 are correct.

 

The most common mechanism of resistance to Isoniazid (INH) in clinical isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis is by a mutation in KatG genes.

The various mechanisms of resistance to INH are:

  • Mutation or deletion of KatG genes: this is the most common mechanism seen in clinical isolates and confers a high level of resistance.
  • Overexpression of genes for InhA: confers a low level of resistance and cross-resistance with ethionamide.
  • Overexpression of genes for ahpC: increases the survival of katG mutants under oxidative stress.
  • Efflux pump induction has also been demonstrated.

Ethambutol inhibits arabinosyl transferase III, thereby disrupting the transfer of arabinose into arabinogalactan biosynthesis which in turn disrupts the assembly of the mycobacterial cell wall. Resistance occurs due to mutations in the embB gene.

Pyrazinamide acts by inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I. Pnca gene mutation is responsible for drug resistance.

Rifampicin acts by inhibiting DNA dependent RNA polymerase. It binds to the β subunit of DNA dependent RNA-polymerase to form a stable drug-enzyme complex and suppresses RNA synthesis. Resistance occurs by mutation in the rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

Note: Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2C19.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A 55-year old man was brought to the OPD with complaints of rapid decline in cognition, impaired position, and vibratory sense. There is a history of sporadic short-term relationships with many promiscuous sexual partners. Romberg’s sign is positive and bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils are seen on checking for pupillary reflex. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above with a positive sexual history, Romberg test, and Argyll Robertson pupils is suggestive of neurosyphilis. The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

The CSF VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/μL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: How does the insecticide derived from the given plant kill the insects?

choices.text: Its a nerve poison, it kils insects on mere contact
Its a stomach poison, it kills the insects after ingestion
It repels the insects for 18-20 hours
It cuts off the air supply of the insects/larvae and kills

questions.solution:
The given plant is pyrethrum(Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium), the extract from the flowers contains pyrethrin which is a nerve poison, which kills insects merely on contact.

Pyrethrum is used as space sprays, sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of fog or mist to kill the insects. These effectively reduce the number of mosquitoes but the effect is temporary as it has no residual action. Reinfestation can occur soon from other areas.

 

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: A structure is marked with a red arrow in the given image. Which of the following actions does it help in?
questions.solution:
Options 2, 4 and 5 are correct.

Points of identification: The lingual nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from the medial surface of lateral pterygoid plate and pyramidal process of the palatine bone. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of mandible
  • Innervation: medial pterygoid branch of the mandibular nerve
  • Actions: Protrusion and elevation of the mandible, side to side movement of the jaw.

questions.text: During the internship, you saw the following x-ray was classified as garden's stage 4 fracture, while going through the case sheets of the admitted patients. Identify the true statements regarding the stages of this classification system.
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows a fracture of the neck of femur and the Garden classification is most commonly used to classify such fractures.

It is based on the degree of displacement.

  • Stage I- incomplete fracture line. The femoral head is in slight valgus
  • Stage II-complete fracture line; nondisplaced
  • Stage III- complete fracture line; partially displaced
  • Stage IV- complete fracture line; completely displaced 

Stages III and IV can be differentiated radiologically by identifying the trabecular patterns.

  • In stage III femoral neck fractures, there is contact between the femoral neck and the head, but the trabecular patterns between the femoral head and acetabulum are not aligned.
  • In stage IV femoral neck fractures, there is no contact between the femoral neck and the head, but the trabecular patterns between the head and acetabulum are realigned.

Note: Pauwels Classification is the other type of Femoral neck Fracture classification system, which is based on the angle, the fracture line

makes in reference to the horizontal.

questions.text: A patient is set to undergo a carotid endarterectomy. Which of the following are correct regarding the surgical anatomy of the concerned artery and the procedure?
questions.solution:
Chassagnaic tubercle/carotid tubercle where pulsations are felt easily is on the C6 vertebrae. 

Clinical significance of common carotid artery:

  • Atheromas are the most common pathology at the bifurcation. They may progress and result in ischemic stroke or transient ischaemic attack (TIA).
  • The level of CCA bifurcation is of surgical importance. Bifurcation is at the upper border of the thyroid cartilage lamina. Bifurcation is found most commonly at the level of the third cervical vertebra.
  • Chassaignac/carotid tubercle/transverse process of C6 vertebra: The pulsations of the common carotid artery can be felt by compressing the artery against this tubercle.
  • In carotid endarterectomy surgeries, most commonly injured nerves are the hypoglossal nerve or marginal mandibular nerve.

questions.text: A young patient who suffered a large wound over the thigh due to RTA was referred to you after initial wound management. As a plastic surgeon, you decide to cover the wound with the following type of graft. Identify the advantages of this graft
questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife. 

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of Thinner split-thickness grafts, the Donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • More durable as they have a greater ability to withstand trauma.
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

questions.text: A 20-year-old student presents to you with the complaints of diplopia and deviation of the right eye as shown in the below image which he developed following a head trauma few months back. Investigations reveal paralysis of the abducent nerve. Which of the following options indicates the features seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of right paralytic squint due to 6th nerve palsy.

Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint in which ocular deviation results from complete or incomplete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles.

Features of paralytic squint:

  • It is mostly acquired or related to traumatic events.
  • History of diplopia present
  • Secondary deviation is greater than the primary deviation.
  • Ocular movements are restricted towards the action of paralyzed muscle.
  • Head is turned towards the action of paralyzed muscle.
  • Visual acuity is normal and there is no amblyopia as the paralytic squint usually develops in adults when visual acuity has already developed. However, if it occurs in children below 6 years than amblyopia can occur.

Forced duction test(FDT) differentiates between the paralytic squint and the restrictive type of squint. In this test, the eye is moved mechanically with the help of a forceps.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. It is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. It is seen in a restrictive squint.

False projection test differentiates the paralytic squint from the non-paralytic squint.

  • It is positive in paralytic squint as the patient cannot correctly locate the object in space when asked to see in the direction of paralysed muscle.
  • It is negative in non-paralytic squint

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman at the onset of labor is wheeled into the CHC. On examination, multiple painful vesicles are present on the labia and on probing into history reveals she has had a burning sensation in the genital area for the past few days. The close-up view of the lesions is as in the image below. What is the management protocol to be followed for this patient?

choices.text: Deliver vaginally and administer the newborn with prophylactic acyclovir
Administer IM benzyl-penicillin to the mother and proceed with vaginal delivery
Deliver the baby by caesarean section
Proceed with vacuum or forceps delivery

questions.solution:
The lesions suggest genital herpes and women who present with these lesions at the onset of labor should be delivered by cesarean section to prevent neonatal herpes.

All pregnant women should be asked about the history of genital herpes and looked for herpetic lesions on examination. Pregnant women who have the first episode of genital herpes or severe recurrent herpes can be treated with oral acyclovir.

Pregnant women who do not have any prodrome or signs and symptoms of genital herpes can deliver vaginally.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with breathing difficulty has a flow-volume loop as given below. What is the likely mechanism which can explain the given loop?

choices.text: Variable intrathoracic obstruction due to tracheomalacia
Restriction due to increased lung elastic recoil
Restriction due to chest wall abnormality

questions.solution:
The given flow-volume loop showing a scooped-out pattern suggests obstruction due to airway narrowing such as acute asthma. 

During an episode of acute asthma, there is a narrowing of the small- and medium-sized airways. This occurs due to constriction of the smooth muscles lining the airways, and inflammatory thickening of the walls of the airways. Because of this, there is a decrease in the maximal expiratory flow during the later part of the flow-volume curve. This produces the scooped-out or coved pattern seen in the flow-volume loop shown. This obstruction cannot be overcome by increasing the expiratory effort, but can be reversed by the use of β2 agonist agents. 

A similar pattern is also seen in COPD because of premature airway closure due to the loss of elastic support of the lung parenchyma on the airways (seen in emphysema) and inflammation of the lower airways (seen in chronic bronchitis). Bronchiectasis and bronchiolitis also show a scooped-out expiratory limb on the flow-volume curve.

 

Any restrictive disease will show a reduction in forced vital capacity (FVC). This is characterized by a smaller flow-volume loop than normal. If the restriction is caused by increased lung recoil (option B), such as interstitial lung disease, there will be a reduction in residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC) as well. RV and TLC usually remain normal if the restriction is caused by chest wall problems (option D).

Variable intrathoracic obstruction (option A) produces a flattening of the expiratory limb of the flow-volume loop, while the inspiratory limb remains normal. The pleural pressure is negative relative to the airway pressure during inspiration, which allows air to flow into the lungs normally despite an airway obstruction. However, the pleural pressure becomes positive relative to the airway pressure during expiration, and this worsens the effect of the obstructive lesion in the airways.

questions.text: During the internship posting in the Ophthalmology OPD, you saw the following procedure is performed by your professor for routine fundus examination. What is the nature of the image formed in this method?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above image is direct ophthalmoscopy and the type of image formed in direct ophthalmoscopy is Erect and Virtual.

Direct Ophthalmoscopy:

  • The most commonly practised method for routine fundus examination
  • The image is erect, virtual and about 15 times magnified
  • Direct ophthalmoscopy should be performed in a semi-darkroom and the patient's right eye should be examined by the right eye of the observer and patient's left eye with the observer's left eye.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present
Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to ora serrata
Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text: An ENT surgeon asks for the following instrument while performing a surgery. This instrument can be used in which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Luc’s forceps. This forceps has a screw joint and the blades are fenestrated, cup-shaped with sharp edges

Luc’s forceps is used in:

  • Caldwell–Luc operation (to remove mucosa),
  • Submucosal resection (SMR) operation (to remove bone or cartilage),
  • During polypectomy (to grasp and avulse polyp) 
  • To take a biopsy from the nose or throat.

Other option:

Tilley’s forceps is used for nasal packing.

questions.text: Which of the following score/staging is correctly paired with the clinical setting in which it is used?
questions.solution:
Options 3, 4, and 5 are correct. 

The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn and thereby calculate the gestational age.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • It can be used to calculate gestational age from 20 to 44 weeks.

  

 

SILVERMAN ANDERSON SCORE for Respiratory distress in newborn:

Score

Upper chest retraction

(Chest movement)

Lower chest retraction

(Intercostal retraction)

 Xiphoid retraction Nasal dilatation

 Grunt
0 Synchronized none none none none
1 Lag on inspiration Just visible Just visible Minimal Stethoscope
2 See-saw Marked marked marked naked ear

 

 

  

Sarnat Staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE): 

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent

Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal,poor light reflex

EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hour if progresses; otherwise, may remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits    

 

 

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria for Necrotizing Enterocolitis

Stage   Intestinal signs Radiological signs Systemic signs
IA   Mild abdominal distention, emesis, and guaiac-positive stool. Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, and lethargy

intact		  IIB + signs of generalized peritonitis  IIB + definite ascites Hypotension, bradycardia, disseminated intravascular coagulation and neutropenia.
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A  IIB +pneumoperitoneum  Same as III A

NEC stage I is suspected NEC; stage II is proven NEC, and stage III is advanced NEC.

 

 

Downe's Score is used for assessment of both term and preterm newborns with respiratory distress whereas Silverman Anderson Score has been validated only in preterm babies.

Downe's score for grading the severity of respiratory distress:

Feature Score 0 Score 1 Score 2

Retractions None Mild Severe

questions.text: During your internship days, You notice the following cylinder attached to an anesthetic machine present in the OT. Which of the following statement is true regarding this cylinder and the inhalational agent present in it?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a blue color cylinder and these cylinders are used to store Nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide is stored in liquid form as the critical temperature of N2O is above room temperature.

Pin index safety system is used to prevent accidental connection of a wrong gas cylinder and the pin index of nitrous oxide cylinder is 3,5

NMDA receptor antagonist which is excitatory receptors in the brain.

As Nitrous oxide diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly, it tends to increase the pressure inside the cavities. Therefore N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Tympanic membrane grafting
  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles

Nitrous oxide increases the likelihood of post operative nausea and vomiting (PONV ) and hence It is avoided in patients at high risk of PONV

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text: A 20 -year-old boy met with an accident. He has been brought to the emergency department where you are posted as an intern. On examination, you notice the following posture with both pupils being unreactive to light. He was making some incomprehensible sounds and his eyes were opening to a painful stimulus. Identify the true statement in this condition?
questions.solution:
The GCS score based on the given clinical scenario and the Decerebrate posturing shown in the above image is 6.

It is calculated as follows

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • Decerebrate posturing/abnormal extension  - 2

In decerebrate posturing, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. Neck and head are extended. 

Classification of severity of injury based on GCS score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury

Note: A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Pupil reactivity score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither 0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

GCS-P score in the given scenario is 4

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.
