The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhoea for the past few hours, and noticed blood in the stool during the recent episodes. He also had two episodes of vomiting. On evaluation, he has a temperature of 39ºC with clinical signs of dehydration. All of the following are indications to initiate empirical antibiotic therapy in this patient, except?
questions.solution:
Two episodes of vomiting are not an indication for antibiotic therapy.

Stool analysis and culture is the initial investigation of choice and antibiotic therapy should be instituted based on microbiological evidence. However, empirical antibiotic therapy may be initiated if diarrhoea persists even with anti-diarrhoeal agents when the patient has grossly bloody stools, fever > 38.5°C, is immunocompromised or is an elderly patient. The empirical antibiotics of choice are either metronidazole or fluoroquinolones.

In a patient with acute diarrhoea, the following are indications for further evaluation:

  1. Profuse diarrhoea with dehydration
  2. Fever > 38.5°C (101°F)
  3. Bloody stools (dysentery)
  4. Duration > 48 hours without improvement
  5. History of recent antibiotic use
  6. Patients aged>50 years with associated acute abdominal pain 
  7. Patients aged>70 years
  8. Immunocompromised patients

The following flowchart highlights the approach to a patient with acute diarrhoea.

questions.text: A young female patient was brought to the emergency room with severe gastrointestinal bleeding. The attenders inform the duty doctor that the patient was on warfarin medications. Her blood group is unknown. The duty doctor can transfuse fresh frozen plasma (FFP) from which of the following blood groups?
questions.solution:
AB fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed as in the above case, wherein the blood group of the patient is not known.

It is to be noted that in cases of active bleeding in a patient on warfarin therapy, prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is recommended over FFP. In case PCC is not available, FFP is used as in the above case.

FFP is plasma prepared from whole blood, either from the primary centrifugation of whole blood into red cells and plasma or from the secondary centrifugation of platelet-rich plasma. The plasma is rapidly frozen to –25°C or colder within 8 hours of collection and contains normal plasma levels of stable clotting factors, albumin, immunoglobulin, and Factor VIII at a level of at least 70% of normal fresh plasma.

Each unit of issued FFP contains a quantity of 200-300 mL.

FFP is capable of transmitting any agent present in cells or plasma, which was undetected by routine screening including HIV, hepatitis B and C, syphilis, and malaria.

Definite indications of FFP transfusion:

  • Replacement of a single coagulation factor deficiency, where a specific or combined factor concentrate is unavailable or contraindicated.
  • Immediate reversal of warfarin effect where prothrombin complex concentrate is unavailable.
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Inherited coagulation inhibitor deficiencies where the specific concentrate is unavailable.
  • C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency where the specific concentrate is unavailable

In an emergency, if crossmatched blood is unavailable:

  • Type O negative pRBCs are indicated for patients with exsanguinating hemorrhage because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens, and thus, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B, or anti-D antibodies in the recipient’s blood.
  • AB plasma is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed because it does not contain antibodies against any antigens on RBCs.

questions.text: A COVID-19 positive patient, who has developed acute respiratory distress syndrome is placed on the ventilator in your ICU. The intensivist advises placing the patient in a prone position. Which of the following statements are correct regarding the prone position?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 2, and 5 are correct.

The prone position in ARDS will help in:

  • Oxygenation is improved
  • Dorsal lung units are exposed to lower pleural pressure
  • Ventral lung units are exposed to higher pleural pressure
  • Promotes pulmonary secretion drainage 
  • It decreases lung strain and stress
  • Reductions in the development of VALI
  • Decreased production of inflammatory cytokines
  • Less regional lung overdistension
  • Decreases regional lung parenchymal heterogeneity.  

Recommendation:

  • Early proning: Within 36 hours of diagnosis of ARDS
  • Long prone sessions: 12-18 hours of proning per session

Complications:

  • airway obstruction
  • endotracheal tube dislodgement,
  • hypotension 
  • arrhythmias,
  • loss of venous access,
  • facial and airway edema
  • greater need for paralysis or sedation

Care must be exercised in patients with:

  • hemodynamic instability,
  • facial or ocular injuries
  • recent sternotomy
  • abdominal incisions

Absolute contraindications:

  • unstable vertebral fractures
  • significantly increased intracranial pressures

questions.text: A 45-year-old man diagnosed with hyperlipoproteinemia due to deficiency of lipoprotein lipase was advised a strict restriction of fat intake in his diet. But he was not compliant to the advice and has a heavy fatty dinner at a get-together party. Which of the following  statements are correct regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, after a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency or apo C-II deficiency (type I hyperlipoproteinemia).

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols).This is called a nascent chylomicron which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL is remodeled into mature chylomicron.

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy.

Clinical correlate: Patients with lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II deficiency (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) hence show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma, after a fatty meal. There is no increased risk of coronary disease in this condition.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: When you were posted as an intern in ortho department. You notice the following 2 angles were used to asses the calcaneal fractures. Identify the true statements regarding the angles shown in the below radiological image.
questions.solution:
The angle depicted as A in the above image is the tuber joint angle of Bohler and The angle depicted as B is the crucial angle of Gissane.

These 2 angles are usually used in the assessment of the calcaneum fractures.

Bohler's angle is the angle between a line drawn to the highest points of the anterior and posterior facets of the calcaneum and a line drawn tangential to the highest point of the calcaneal tuberosity. This angle ranges from 20 to 40 degrees and is decreased in the calcaneal fractures.

The crucial angle of Gissane is formed by the downward and upward slopes of the calcaneal superior surface. This angle ranges from 95 to 105 degrees and it is increased in intraarticular fracture of calcaneum.

Related Pearl: Important angles used in the diagnosis of Orthopedic conditions

questions.text: An obstetrician performs a procedure for labor induction on a patient which is depicted in the image below. Which among the following is false about it?

choices.text: It is based on Ferguson reflex
It is associated with raised blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolites
It is a simple and safe method of induction of labor
It is done after artificial rupture of membranes

questions.solution:
The method of labor induction being depicted in the image is the stripping of membranes. This is done prior to the artificial rupture of membranes (ARM).

Stripping/Sweeping: Digital separation of chorio-amniotic membranes from the wall of the cervix & lower uterine segment. This helps in labor induction by eliciting the Ferguson reflex.

Ferguson reflex/Fetal ejection reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite (PGFM). The release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has also been suggested as a possible mechanism.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding umbilical cord blood banking:
questions.solution:
1. The umbilical vein is used for collecting the Umbilical Cord Blood (UCB) which is stored in Cord blood banks that can be private, public or hybrid banks.
  2. Transplantation of UCB is indeed possible across HLA barriers. UCB has a lower risk of graft versus host disease compared to conventional HSCT from peripheral blood and bone marrow.
  3. UCB from unaffected (not any) matched sibling donor can be used for thalassemia transplants.
  4. The role of UCB in diseases like BPD, HIE where the regenerative property of the stem cells is utilized, is still under research and hence limited to clinical trials only at present. So, currently, there is no scientific data to prove that autologous cord blood is of any value for regenerative medical purposes.
  5. The risk of having a disease curable by autologous transplant is very low in low-risk families. It is only around (0.04 to 0.0005%).

questions.text: A student was asked to record ECG by using bipolar limb leads. The below image shows the arrangement of the bipolar electrodes and the potentials recorded across lead I and lead II. What is the potential recorded across lead III?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven’s law, the potential recorded across lead III is +0.7 mV.

Einthoven’s Law: Einthoven’s law states that if the ECGs are recorded simultaneously with the three limb leads, the sum of the potentials recorded in leads I and III will equal the potential in lead II.

Lead I potential + Lead III potential = Lead II potential

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (1.2-0.5) = +0.7 mV.

Note: Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary triangle drawn around the area of the heart. It is formed by the arrangement of three bipolar limb leads (the two arms and left leg).

Related Pearl: ECG Leads

LA – Left arm: RA – Right arm: LL – Left leg: LF – Left foot

  • Limb leads measure the electrical activity in the frontal plane
  • Chest leads measure the electrical activity in the horizontal plane

questions.text: The histology slide of a patient with renal cell carcinoma is as shown in the image below. While looking at the clinical history attached to the lab request, you learn that this patient also has cerebellar hemangioblastoma and retinal angiomatosis. This would lead you to suspect which of the following conditions in the patient?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows clear cell renal carcinoma, which along with the history of cerebellar hemangioblastoma and retinal angiomatosis is suggestive of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. 

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is characterized by a predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina. Hundreds of bilateral renal cysts, often multiple, clear cell carcinomas develop in 40% to 60% of affected persons. Those with VHL syndrome inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. A 'second hit' can lead to manifestations.

ORGAN SYSTEM

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

VHL: von Hippel–Lindau

RCC: Renal cell carcinoma

PTEN: phosphatase and tensin homolog gene

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: The following pattern  is visualised in an agarose gel by ethidium bromide staining of DNA fragments. Which of the following statements is incorrect about pathway suggested by the given image?
questions.solution:
I and 5 are incorrect.

The stepladder pattern , classical of apoptosis is shown in the image above.

Puma and Noxa are stress sensors, along with BAD, BIM, and BID. They are also called BH3-only proteins which block the function of BCL2 and BCL-XL.

Functions of BH3 proteins:

  • act as sensors of cellular stress and damage ( eg: cells deprived of survival signals, DNA damage, or accumulation of misfolded proteins which induce ER stress)
  • regulate the balance between the pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins
  • activate the two critical pro-apoptotic factors, BAX and BAK
  • block the function of BCL2 and BCL-XL

BCL-2, BCL-XL, and MCL-1 belong to the anti-apoptotic family.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and stiffness on opening the mouth. On examination, the parotid gland is enlarged as shown below and tender. How long will this child be considered infectious, considering the most likely diagnosis based on the given features?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir

questions.solution:
The boy in this case is most likely suffering from Mumps. Once the swelling subsides, the boy will no longer be infectious.

Mumps is an infectious disease caused by an RNA virus from the paramyxoviridae family. The period of communicability is usually 4-6 days prior to the appearance of symptoms, but once the swelling subsides, the patient can be regarded as no longer infectious. Infection is caused by air droplets through the respiratory route. The high secondary attack rate of 86%

Clinical features:

  • The incubation period ranges from 12 to 25 days (usually 16-18 days).
  • Prodrome period: fever, headache, vomiting and achiness.
  • Parotitis, subligual and submandibular glands may also be involved.
  • Oedema over sternum as a result of lymphatic obstruction may occur. Morbilliform rash is rarely seen.

Complications of Mumps:

  • Parotitis: Unilateral or Bilateral, non-suppurative.
  • Epididymo-orchitis: Usually unilateral.
  • Meningitis or Meningoencephalitis
  • Other complications include: Arthritis, oophoritis, nephritis, pancreatitis, thyroiditis and myocarditis

questions.text: Some interventions from the government can help in altering human behavior either directly or indirectly. Which of the following are examples of this regulatory approach to health education?
questions.solution:
Options 1 and 4 are correct.

Regulations may take many forms, a prohibition to imprisonment. Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act, Prohibition of alcohol, and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve personal choices like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach
Regulatory approach Service approach  Health Education approach Primary health care approach
Government intervention to alter human behavior laws Facilities are provided by the government for use Awareness-> interest->Evaluation The health of the people, for the people, by the people where principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed
Ex: Child marriage Act, No smoking in public places; Helmet law, compulsory seat belt use, Prohibition of Alcohol Ex: Government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt Ex: 

use of safe water supply, fertility control

questions.text: A young female, who presented with the history of intermittent attacks of pallor and cyanosis in the upper limbs was diagnosed to be suffering from Raynaud’s disease. Which of the following options represents the correct sequence of events seen in this condition?

choices.text: Local syncope > Local recovery >  Local asphyxia >local gangrene
Local asphyxia > Local recovery >  Local syncope > local gangrene
Local syncope > Local asphyxia > Local recovery > local gangrene
Local asphyxia > Local syncope > Local recovery > local gangrene

questions.solution:
Local syncope > Local asphyxia > Local recovery > local gangrene represents the correct sequence of events seen in Raynaud’s disease.

Raynaud’s disease: It is a disease of young women and the upper limbs are affected more commonly than the lower limbs. In Raynaud's disease, a number of attacks can be seen and each attack is comprised of 3 stages i.e,

  • Local syncope, in which the affected digits become cold and white with tingling and numbness. These changes are due to spasm of the digital arteries.
  • Local asphyxia, in which the white digits turn blue with a burning sensation. This change is due to the slowing of circulation and accumulation of reduced haemoglobin.
  • Local recovery, in which the bluish discolouration gradually disappears and the digits regain normal colour due to release of spasm of digital arteries.
  • Such attacks are repeated, till the patches of superficial ulceration and gangrene appear at the fingertips, which is known as local gangrene.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the emergency room with nausea,  vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to the usual doses of analgesics. The pain typically radiates to the back and is slightly relieved in the sitting forward position. The following signs are seen on examination. All of the following is used for assessing the severity of the given condition except
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the Grey Turner sign (A) and Cullen's sign (B) shown in the picture, is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All the above criteria can be used for assessing the severity of Acute pancreatitis except Rosemont’s criteria.

Rosemont’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis and is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. 

Revised Atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of acute pancreatitis.

Atlanta classification:

Mild Acute Pancreatitis

  • No organ failure
  • No local or systemic complications

Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or
  • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure

Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours)–single organ or multiorgan

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

Related Pearl: Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis

  Parenchymal features Ductal features
Major criteria Major A criteria:
  • Hyperechoic foci with post-acoustic shadowing
Major B criteria:
  • Honeycombing lobularity
 Major A criteria:
  • Main pancreatic duct calculi
Minor criteria
  • Hyperechoic, non-shadowing foci ≥3 mm in length and width
  • Lobularity including three or more noncontiguous lobules in the body or tail
  • Pancreatic cysts ≥2 mm in short axis
  • At least three strands*

   *Strands are defined as hyperechoic lines ≥3 mm in length seen in at least two different directions in the body or tail of the pancreas.
  • Irregular main pancreatic duct (MPD) contour
  • Dilated side branches+
  • Main pancreatic duct dilation (≥3.5 mm in the body or ≥1.5 mm in the tail)
  • Hyperechoic MPD margin >50% of the main pancreatic duct in the body and tail.

 +≥3 tubular anechoic structures, each one ≥1 mm in width, budding from MPD
  Diagnosis of Chronic Pancreatitis:
  • Consistent with chronic pancreatitis
    • 1 major A criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • 1 major A criterion + major B criterion
    • 2 major A criteria
  • Suggestive of chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 1 major A criterion + <3 minor criteria
    • 1 major B criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • ≥5 minor criteria
  • Indeterminate for chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 3-4 minor criteria in the absence of major criteria
    • Major B criterion + <3 minor criteria
  •  Normal
    • <3 minor criteria

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to you with the following deformity in the right upper limb, which developed after suffering a fall on an outstretched hand. Identify the true statement regarding the fracture leading to this deformity?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dinner fork deformity seen in Colles' fracture.

Colles' fracture is the transverse fracture of the distal end of the radius just above the wrist, with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. The common mode of injury is fall on an outstretched hand.

Dinner fork deformity is a classical deformity seen in Colles’ fracture, however, it is not found in all cases but seen only if there is a dorsal displacement and dorsal tilt of the distal fragment.

Normally, the tip of radial styloid process is situated distal to the tip of ulnar styloid process. In Colles' fracture, the radial styloid process comes to lie at the same level as of the ulnar styloid process and is found in all displacements of Colles’ fracture. Hence, this is a more reliable sign than dinner fork deformity.

Treatment:

  • For undisplaced fracture: Immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks.
  • For displaced fractures: Fracture reduction followed by application of below-elbow Colles' cast extending up to the metacarpal heads, immobilizing the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

Note: Malunion is seen more commonly seen in Colles' fracture due to improper reduction and inadequate immobilization.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: You are posted in pediatrics OPD as an intern. A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent fractures and poorly-developed teeth. Examination reveals joint laxity and blue sclera. Both parents are phenotypically normal. Your senior asks you to interpret the mode of inheritance in this case from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent fractures, poorly developed teeth with blue sclera, and joint laxity is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta is an example of gonadal mosaicism where phenotypically normal parents can have more than one affected child.

It is a type of autosomal dominant disorder where some patients do not have phenotypically affected parents. The disorder can result from a new mutation in the egg or the sperm from which the zygote was formed. The siblings may or may not be affected. In some cases, mosaicism can result from a mutation that occurs after the formation of the zygote, during early (embryonic) development.

A phenotypically normal parent who has gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated ova/sperm. Therefore, there is a possibility that more than one child of such a parent can be affected.

Other options:

Option A- In X-linked recessive conditions, an affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons but all daughters will be carriers of the disease. Sons of heterozygous women have a chance of inheriting the mutant gene.

Option B- In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

Option C- Genomic imprinting is the transcriptional silencing of either maternal or paternal allele. Prader-Willi syndrome is paternal imprinting (deletion of paternal chromosome15 in 65-75% of individuals), maternal uniparental disomy 15 (20-30%), or an imprinting defect; and Angelman syndrome is due to maternal imprinting (deletion of maternal chromosome 15).

questions.text: A pregnant woman with 7 weeks of gestation is undergoing an abortion with the given instrument. Which among the following is false considering the instrument/procedure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a manual vacuum aspiration syringe, used in manual vacuum aspiration. Options 2 and 3 are false about it.

It is used for early pregnancy failures or elective termination for up to 12 weeks. The negative pressure of 660 mmHg is created and products of conception are aspirated.

This procedure takes less time and is less traumatic. It can be done on an OPD basis, using a plastic disposable cannula (up to 12 mm size) and a 60 mL plastic (double valve) syringe

Uses

  • MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy)
  • Incomplete abortion, Missed abortion, Molar Pregnancy
  • Endometrial aspiration.

The above image is of Karman cannula. It is a long tubular structure made of plastic or metal. It is available in sizes 4 to 12 mm, the number of cannulas corresponds to the diameter in millimetres. It has a superior overhanging edge acting as a curette. A plastic cannula is preferred because it is less traumatic, and disposable, the products sucked out can be seen during suctioning as it is transparent. The vacuum must be broken before it is withdrawal.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: An ENT resident performs the following procedure under general anesthesia to wash out the pus in a patient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. This patient is usually placed in which of the following positions while performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above image is proof puncture (antral lavage). While performing this procedure under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position 

Proof puncture (antral lavage): This procedure involves puncturing the medial wall of the maxillary sinus in the region of the inferior meatus and irrigating the sinus.

Indications:

  • Chronic and subacute maxillary sinusitis with dual purpose of confirming the diagnosis and washing out the pus.
  • To collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

Contraindications:

  • Acute maxillary sinusitis for fear of osteomyelitis.

Note: Sitting position is preferred in all adults when using local anesthesia. But under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position 

Rose position is a surgical position that involves head and neck extension with a sandbag near the shoulder blade as shown in the below image.


Other options:

Barking-dog position is a surgical position in which the neck is flexed on the thorax and the head is extended on atlanto-occipital joint. This position is used during laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and oesophagoscopy.


Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with the head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.


Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions and for patients with a nasogastric tube.

questions.text: The following subunit vaccines are recombinant protein vaccines:
questions.solution:
HBV, HPV, and cholera toxin-B are recombinant protein vaccines. Anthrax vaccine is a toxoid and Hib is a Polysaccharide vaccine.

Recombinant protein vaccines: With the help of recombinant DNA technology, the purified recombinant proteins from the cultured microorganisms result in cleaner vaccine preparations with a better safety profile. Examples include HBV, HPV, Lyme disease, Cholera toxin-B.

Toxoids: Some organisms produce toxoids, which can be highly efficacious immunizing agents. Examples include Diptheria, Tetanus, Acellular pertussis, Anthrax.

questions.text: You are examining a veterinarian in the OPD, who has presented with fever and a black eschar on his forearm. You make a provisional diagnosis of anthrax and want to start him on appropriate antibiotics based on CDC guidelines. Which of the following is not correct regarding the treatment and post-exposure guidelines for anthrax?

choices.text: If he has uncomplicated cutaneous anthrax, it can be treated with fluoroquinolones or doxycycline
In case he develops anthrax meningitis, antibiotic treatment should be given for 60 days
In systemic anthrax, only antimicrobial drugs would be indicated in management
Post-exposure prophylaxis for inhalation anthrax in adult cases requires treatment for 60 days

questions.solution:
For patients with suspected systemic anthrax, a combination of antitoxin and antimicrobial drug treatment should be given.

 CDC guidelines on anthrax post-exposure (PEP) and treatment include the following:

  • Uncomplicated cutaneous anthrax can be treated with a single oral agent fluoroquinolones or doxycycline for 7-14 days.
  • For patients with suspected systemic anthrax, a combination of antitoxin and antimicrobial drug treatment should be given.
  • Antitoxin (antibody against protective antigen) is used with antibiotics:
  •    Human anthrax immunoglobulin (Anthrasil)
  •    Monoclonal antibodies to protective antigen Obiltoxaximab or Roxibacumab.These are indicated in severe cases with systemic involvement, such as  inhalational anthrax because antibiotics do not affect the toxin once it is formed.
  • In cases of anthrax meningitis, at least three antimicrobial drugs including clindamycin should be given for 60 days, irrespective of their vaccine strains.
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for inhalation anthrax in adults-ciprofloxacin and doxycycline along with vaccine (AVABioThrax) are first-line treatment for 60 days.

questions.text: A child was referred to dermatology  OPD  with the complaints of rashes on the body. There was no history suggestive of itching or discomfort from the lesions. On examination, pale, firm papules measuring about 1–3 mm were noted and a provisional diagnosis of Miliaria profunda was made. What is the level of blockade of eccrine glands in this condition?
questions.solution:
In miliaria profunda, the rupture of the eccrine sweat duct occurs at the level of dermal-epidermal junction or even below.

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat glands.

The level of blockade in miliaria is:

Miliaria crystallina Stratum corneum
Miliaria rubra Malphigian layer
Miliaria profunda Dermoepidermal junction

 

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with the complaint that she needs to check if the front door of her home is locked at least 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She understands that this habit is irrational but she feels extremely anxious due to repetitive thoughts that her door is unlocked but has not been treated for the condition before.  which of these management options would you suggest for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder which can be managed by behavior therapy.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

Behavior therapy and pharmacotherapy can be used alone or in combination for the management of this condition. Behavior therapy is thought to be longer-lasting than pharmacotherapy. Hence, it is considered the treatment of choice by many clinicians. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or clomipramine are used for medical management.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviors are called compulsions, such as counting and checking, and are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

It is associated with other mental disorders such as major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and specific phobias. In adults, it is seen with equal prevalence among men and women. The four major symptom patterns include contamination, pathological doubt, intrusive thoughts, and symmetry.

Other options:

Option A: Cingulotomy is carried out in severe and treatment-unresponsive patients.

Option B: Electroconvulsive therapy can be considered in treatment-resistant and chronically debilitating conditions.

Option D: Antipsychotics such as risperidone have been helpful in some cases when added to the treatment.

 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

questions.text: You are an intensivist and you are evaluating for brain death in a patient in ICU. Which of the following points are correct regarding the assessment for brain death?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 2, 3 and 5 are correct.

Brain death is the irreversible cessation of all cerebral function with the preservation of cardiac activity and maintenance of respiratory and somatic function by artificial means. It is legally equivalent to death. It can be assessed bedside.

In brain death, the pupils are usually midsized or maybe dilated. However, constricted pupils are not seen. 

The diagnosis of brain death should be confirmed with the following clinical findings:

  • The absent brain-originating motor response, including response to pain stimulus above the neck or other brain-originating movements (eg, seizures, decerebrate or decorticate posturing)
  • Unresponsiveness to any stimuli,
  • Brainstem damage as evidenced by dilated or mid-sized pupils without light reaction.
  • Absent corneal, gag and oculovestibular reflexes
  • Absent sucking or rooting reflexes
  • Absent cough with tracheal suctioning
  • Apnea, indicating medullary destruction.
  • The heart rate should be invariant and does not accelerate to atropine.

Confirmatory test findings (optional, not mandatory)

  • Isoelectric electroencephalogram
  • Absence of brainstem auditory evoked potentials
  • Absence of cerebral perfusion as documented by angiographic, transcranial Doppler, or radioisotopic studies

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: When you are posted as an intern in the surgery department, You notice the senior resident performing the following test in a patient diagnosed with Glucoganoma. Identify the true statement with respect to this scenario
questions.solution:
The given image shows the method of eliciting the “ Moses sign ", which is calf pain/tenderness on applying direct pressure over calf muscles seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT).

Glucagonoma is a rare syndrome, with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis(positive Homan’s sign and Moses Sign is suggestive of DVT), and depression.

Necrolytic migrating erythema/skin rash is a characteristic skin lesion seen in glucagonoma patients usually before the appearance of other symptoms It is thought to be caused by low levels of amino acids. Therefore  Parenteral administration of amino acids was found to result in the disappearance of the skin lesions.

 

 

Note:

Calf tenderness on forced ankle dorsiflexion is known as Homans sign

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A  baby with the following deformity was referred to you by a pediatrician. You decide to manage this case conservatively based on Ponsetti’s method. Which of the following steps you would follow under this method?
questions.solution:
Ponsetti's method is the currently used method for conservative management of CTEV. Previously Kite's method was followed.

In this method, The foot is treated by manipulating and applying PoP cast within first week of life. The cavus aspect of the deformity is corrected first, followed by the adduction, then varus, and lastly equinus.

An above-knee cast is applied after every manipulation.

The applied cast is usually changed once in every week (i.e. every 5-7 days)

It is usually possible to correct all components of the deformity within 6 weeks but the equinus deformity usually remains undercorrected, and can be treated by percutaneous tenotomy of tendoachilles.

The following table shows the differences between Ponset's and kite's method of CTEV management.

  Ponseti's method Kite's method
Treatment starts at  within first week of life around 1 month
Order of correction cavus -adduction - varus- equinus adduction - inversion -equinus
Fulcrum while manipulating Head of talus Calcaneocuboid joint
POP type Above knee cast Below knee cast

questions.text: A 42-year-old diabetic male has been in the post-operative surgery ward with a central line inserted for the past 8 days. He develops a high-grade fever, cough, confusion and his respiratory rate is 32/minute and BP is 100/70 mm Hg. Laboratory results show raised blood counts and 1,3 Beta D Glucan levels of ≥80 pg/mL. Which of the following organisms is not a likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
In the given diagnostic assay 1,3 beta D Glucan assay levels of ≥80 pg/mL is considered positive. Invasive cryptococcosis is not detected by this assay.  

The given scenario can be a case of invasive fungal infection (candida, aspergillus ) which can occur in post-operative cases through contaminated central lines.

1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, more commonly in candida, aspergillus and pneumocystis jiroveci.  

However, it is not used in the diagnosis of cryptococci, the zygomycetes, and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.  

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. These cells contain components of the Limulus clotting cascade, including factors C and G, which initiate coagulation in the presence of bacterial liposaccharide and Beta D Glucan, respectively. By eliminating factor C from the lysate, the manufacturers limit activation of the cascade to BDG alone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who has never had chickenpox now comes in contact with a person diagnosed with primary varicella infection. Which of the following regarding the management of the given case is true?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 2, and 3 are true

A pregnant woman with a negative history of chickenpox, when exposed to primary varicella infection, should undergo VZV serological testing. Seropositive are immune while seronegative individuals should receive varicella-zos­ter immune globulin (VariZIG). It is best given within 96 hours of exposure, although it is approved up till day 10. Women with a previous history of varicella need not receive the immunoglobulin.

The attenuated live virus vaccine is not recommended in pregnant women. However, the vaccine is not secreted in breast milk, therefore vaccination should not be delayed because of breastfeeding.

Intrauterine infections associated with limb reduction defects and scarring of skin are associated with congenital varicella syndrome. It is transmitted by the mother who is a case of chickenpox.

The highest risk of fetal varicella syndrome is when maternal infection develops within 13–20 weeks.

The characteristic cutaneous lesion is called cicatrix, zigzag scarring, in a dermatomal distribution, and it is often associated with atrophy of the affected limb.

Features of fetal varicella syndrome:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy,
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

Where fetuses/neonates exposed to the active infection before/during delivery when mothers haven't developed the antibody yet, the newborns are at serious risk, as the mortality rate is 30%. Therefore VZIG should be administered to newborns whose mothers have clinical features 5 days before and up to 2 days after the delivery.

questions.text:
The image given below shows the mechanism of a component of the immune system's first line of defense against infection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the release of these substances from the cell?

SLE- Systemic lupus erythematosus

choices.text: It results in the loss of nucleus.
It is effective only against bacteria.
It is implicated in the pathogenesis of  SLE.

questions.solution:
The gif shows fibrous neutrophilic extracellular traps (NETs) released from a neutrophil. NETs are mainly effective against bacteria and fungi.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are the meshwork of nuclear chromatin of neutrophils. The loss of nuclei leads to the death of the neutrophils. They concentrate on antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to fight against bacteria and fungi (not viruses). They are detected in the blood during sepsis. They are produced by neutrophils in response to

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

Note: The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with the following ophthalmic findings presented to you with restricted eye movements with chemosis.  You diagnose Graves's ophthalmopathy in this patient. Which of the following lid signs you would identify in this patient?
questions.solution:
Among the given options Von Graefe’s sign, Enroth’s sign, and Gifford’s sign are the lid signs seen in the Graves's ophthalmopathy.

Lid Signs:

  • Von Graefe’s sign ( Lid lag sign ): When globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind.
  • Enroth’s sign: Fullness of eyelids due to puffy oedematous swelling.
  • Gifford’s sign: Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
  • Stellwag’s sign: Infrequent blinking.
  • Dalrymple's sign: Retraction of the upper lids

Other Options:

Decreased power of convergence is known as Mobius sign and is due to defect in ocular motility.

Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze is known as Joffroy’s sign.

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Sign Feature
Dalrymple's sign Retraction of the upper lids
von Graefe's sign Lid lag, i.e., when the globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind
Griffith Sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze
Enroth's sign Fullness of the eyelids
Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
Mobius’ sign Convergence weakness
Joffroy’s sign Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze
Jellinek's Sign Abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid

The image given below shows Dalrymple's sign in the right eye.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive obese patient on medication presents to you with a history of constipation and weight gain. His examination shows delayed relaxation of the ankle jerk compared to a normal subject. All of the following may lead to this finding except?
questions.solution:
Delayed relaxation of ankle jerk is known as Woltman's sign and is associated with hypothyroidism, beta-blocker usage, rigidity due to neurological disorder. It is not caused due to L4-L5 disc prolapse. Woltmann's sign is particularly associated with a slowing down of the relaxation phase. 

With the rapid and easy availability of thyroid function tests, it has less usage in clinical practice.

Mechanism of Woltman's sign: Hyporeflexia is related to decreased muscle levels of myosin ATPase, this causes a delay in muscle contraction and slowing in reaccumulation of calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Conditions associated with this sign are: 

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • Advanced age
  • Drugs( beta-blockers)
  • Hypothermia
  • Multiple neurological conditions 

Neurological features in L4-L5 disc prolapse include:

  • Weakness of extensor hallucis longus and dorsiflexors of the foot.
  • Sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the lower thigh, anterolateral aspect of knee and leg, dorsum of the foot, and the great toe and one or more adjacent toes (i.e., 1st webspace) but never the little toe.
  • Normal knee jerk and ankle jerk

Related Pearl: Neurological examination in Intervertebral disc prolapse (IVDP)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female has complaints of marked dryness in her mouth associated with difficulty in swallowing. Schirmer's test is suggestive of severe dry eye. An immunoassay shows the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies. Which of the following drugs would be most helpful, with fewer side effects, in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms together with the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies are suggestive of Sjogren syndrome. Cevimeline would be the best drug for treatment in this case.

Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist with an affinity for both M1 and M3 receptors on the lacrimal and salivary glands. While M1 activation results in increased secretion, M3 activation results in smooth muscle contraction, and expulsion of the secretions.

Cevimeline enhances lacrimal secretions in Sjögren’s syndrome.

Cevimeline has a long-lasting sialogogic action. The usual dose is 30 mg three times daily. It has fewer side effects than non-selective pilocarpine.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman who is in her 8th week of gestation presents with an increased frequency of vomiting which is associated with retching. She shows signs of dehydration and has developed oliguria. Investigations reveal associated ketoacidosis. All of the following are associated with the condition that this patient has, except ____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests hyperemesis gravidarum. Low body mass is a risk factor associated with it(not high).

Hyperemesis gravidarum is more common in women with low BMI. Unrelenting nausea and vomiting that is severe enough causes weight loss, dehydration, ketosis, alkalosis, or hypokalemia is known as hypermesis gravidarum.

It is associated with the following factors:

  • First pregnancy
  • Young age
  • Low body mass
  • History of migraine/motion sickness
  • Positive family history
  • Hydatidiform mole and multi-foetal gestation

Patients with hyperemesis gravidarum usually also suffer from a transient clinical or subclinical form of hyperthyroidism.

Management of hyperemesis gravidarum: Mild to moderate symptoms can be treated with dietary modifications,  vitamin B6 with doxylamine/diphenhydramine. Severe cases need IV hydration with thiamine and parenteral ondansetron/metoclopramide/promethazine.

questions.text: You just finished your COVID duty hours and proceeded for doffing the PPE kit. The component of the kit to be removed last is?
questions.solution:
The component of the PPE kit to be removed last as per CDC guidelines is the mask.

PPE or the personal protective equipment consists of:

  • Gloves – to protect hands
  • Gowns/aprons – to protect skin and/or clothing
  • Masks and respirators– to protect mouth/nose – Respirators – protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents
  • Goggles – to protect eyes
  • Face shields – to protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes

There are 2 sequences that are recommended by the CDC for the removal of PPE:

Sequence 1 Sequence 2

GLOVES

 ↓

GOGGLES OR FACE SHIELD

↓

GOWN 

↓

MASK OR RESPIRATOR

GOWN AND GLOVES   

↓

GOGGLES OR FACE SHIELD 

↓

MASK OR RESPIRATOR

 

 

Images given above are related to doffing of the PPE.

 

The sequence of Donning/Putting on the PPE: 

  • Identify and gather the proper PPE
  • Perform hand hygiene using hand sanitizer
  • Put on the isolation gown
  • Put on NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirator or higher (use a facemask if a respirator is not available)
  • Put on face shield or goggles
  • Put on gloves

The image given above is related to the donning of the PPE.

questions.text: During the rounds in the NICU, you examine the neonates. You would be correct to classify which of the following neonates as having apnea?
questions.solution:
Apnea is defined as the cessation of breathing for longer than 20 sec, or for a shorter duration in the presence of bradycardia or change in skin color (pallor or cyanosis).

Apnea is a pathological cessation of breathing that results in hemodynamic disturbances and merits treatment.

In contrast, Periodic breathing is a normal event in preterm infants, that reflects the respiratory control system immaturity and does not merit any treatment. 30-45% of preterm neonates exhibit periodic breathing pattern characterized by three or more respiratory pauses of greater than 3 seconds duration.

Note:

Significant bradycardia is defined as heart rate <80 bpm and

Significant desaturation is defined as oxygen saturation <80-85%.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child was brought to the emergency in cardiac arrest. Which of the following technique of chest compressions is the best to be followed in this scenario?

choices.text: Thumb of 1 hand, with other fingers encircled on left side of chest.
Heel of 1 hand over lower half of sternum
2 thumbs on sternum, with hands encircling the chest
2 fingers i.e. index and middle finger on lower 1/3rd of sternum

questions.solution:
In children of age >1 year, the heel of the palm on lower 1/3rd of the sternum is applied during chest compressions.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths in a minute. i.e 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if second rescuer arrives)

In infants:

2 thumb technique with hands encircling the chest over the sternum is the method to be followed in infants. The 2 finger technique and 2 thumb technique are considered equally effective.

The thumbs or the tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release. In infants, the brachial pulse should be assessed. (For children aged one to adolescence, the pulse should be checked at the carotid artery).

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl was admitted with a large wound on her thigh for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. She was given an antibiotic that binds to the subunit of the ribosome marked by the red cross and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. Identify the drug given to this patient.

MRSA- Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
The drug given in this case is Linezolid which binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, vancomycin-resistant staphylococci. Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability approaches 100%.

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA). Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse efffects of linezolid:

  • Myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • Thrombocytopenia (most common side effect) 
  • Serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition
  • Mitochondrial toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

Clinical correlate- Intravenous and oral doses for linezolid are the same because of 100% bioavailability.

Other options:

Option A - Chloramphenicol primarily binds reversibly to the 50S ribosomal subunit. It blocks the amino acid–containing end of the aminoacyl tRNA from binding to the acceptor site on the 50S ribosomal subunit. This prevents the peptide bond formation by breaking the interaction between peptidyl transferase and its amino acid substrate. One of the most important adverse effects of chloramphenicol is grey baby syndrome.

Option C - Vancomycin is a glycopeptide. It inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding with D-alanyl-D-alanine. It is used in the treatment of MRSA, clostridium difficile, and enterococci. Redman syndrome, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are the most important adverse effects.

Option D - Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside. Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis. Their ability to cause misreading of DNA template and the formation of aberrant proteins that get incorporated into bacterial cell membrane makes them bactericidal agents. Their antimicrobial activity reduces in an anaerobic environment. Ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade are the most important adverse effects.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. He says he tasted a small colorful graphic blotting paper while at the party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. Later, he develops extreme paranoia and extreme panic and starts crying. Examination of the eyes shows mydriasis. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse. The patient developed extreme panic and paranoia after tasting a small colorful blotting paper, which is suggestive of a bad trip. Other features that support this diagnosis are palpitation, profuse sweating, tremors, and pupillary dilation.

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc. Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. 

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other named effects of drug use:

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - This is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.
  • Magnan syndrome - This is a type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

Other options:

Option A: Cannabis intoxication causes feelings of detachment, euphoria, relaxation, decreased concentration, and attention span. Images appear vivid. There is increased thirst and appetite.

Option B: Amphetamine intoxication also gives rise to similar clinical features like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, tremors, dilated pupils, and paranoia. However, the ingestion of blotting paper, makes LSD more likely.

Option D: Cocaine intoxication may also have similar features, like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, dilated pupils, and altered behavior. It also causes anesthesia in the area that has been in direct contact with the drug. Magnan syndrome may also be seen.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance

Shows a biphasic pattern.

questions.text: At your clinic, the instrument seen in the image below slips from your hand and is broken. You would carefully discard it in _____.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a mercury-containing clinical thermometer, this contains heavy metal and if broken are considered as chemical waste and therefore must be carefully discarded in the yellow container.
