questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented to the ER with respiratory distress along with abdominal distension. On auscultation, basal crackles were heard on bilateral chest fields. She is visibly icteric and her fingers show clubbing. History reveals tobacco and alcohol dependence. As a medicine resident on duty, you do abdominal paracentesis to relieve her abdominal distension. About 6.5 litres of fluid is removed in total from the patient. Which of the following is a correct statement regarding the procedure?

choices.text: Right- upper quadrant is the preferred site
Removal of a large volume of ascitic fluid may cause hypernatremia
Usage of IV albumin reduces post-tap circulatory dysfunction
Elevated PT/INR is an absolute contraindication

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a large volume paracentesis being done to remove ascitic fluid secondary to likely liver pathology. Usage of IV albumin as a plasma expander makes up for the proteins lost in ascitic fluid. It also reduces post-paracentesis circulatory dysfunction.

Post-paracentesis circulatory dysfunction (PPCD) is characterized by the activation of the RAAS system and increased renin levels. It causes rapid re-accumulation of ascitic fluid.

Other options:

Left or right lower quadrants are preferred to avoid puncturing the liver or spleen.

Large-volume paracentesis is associated with hyponatremia, renal impairment, and hepatic encephalopathy.

Elevated PT/INR is not an absolute contraindication unless there is an overt DIC or signs of fibrinolysis (oozing from IV sites or ongoing visible bleeding) are present.

Grades of  ascites:

Grade Definition Treatment
1

Clinical sign-negative

Diagnosed by USG

 Salt restriction (2.5gm/day)
2

Clinical sign-positive

No respiratory distress

 Add diuretic-Spironolactone /Furosemide
3 Respiratory distress Large-volume paracentesis (5-6l fluid removed+IV albumin (1-2gm/L fluid removed)
Refractory

No response to the maximum dose of diuretics

  • Spironolactone 400 mg/day
  • Furosemide 160 mg/day

 

Large-volume paracentesis (5-6l fluid removed+IV albumin (6-8gm/L fluid removed)

Best treatment-TIPS (transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt)

 

Clinical signs associated with ascites:

Finding volume(ml)
Puddle sign positive 120 
Shifting dullness 500
Fluid thrill 1500

questions.text: Among the following tests that have been ordered, which is an example of 'diagnostic test'?

choices.text: Endocervical culture of N. Gonorrhoea in a 24 year old female with Dyspareunia and vaginal discharge
VDRL test to detect syphilis in a 21 year old pregnant female that has come to the AN clinic
Fasting and Post Prandial blood sugar testing in a 43 year old businesswoman that has come for her annual health checkup
Serological test for HIV in a 42 year old male that has come for voluntary blood donation

questions.solution:
Endocervical culture is an example of a diagnostic test.

The difference between terms screening, case finding, and diagnostic test is distinct.

Screening: tests done in individuals/populations who were not seeking health care. Eg: premarital screening for syphilis, neonatal screening, serological test for AIDS virus in blood donors, etc

Case-finding: tests done to detect diseases in people seeking health care for other reasons. Eg: VDRL test to detect syphilis in pregnant women, detecting other diseases like pulmonary TB in chest symptomatic, cervical cancer, breast cancer, diabetes mellitus, etc

Diagnostic tests: tests done to confirm/refute the existence of a disease. Eg: Endocervical culture of N. Gonorrhoea, VDRL test in patients with lesions suggestive of secondary syphilis, etc

questions.text: You have to start anticoagulation therapy in a few patients admitted in the Medicine IPD.  You will be watchful regarding which of the following co-morbidities and side effects while starting these drugs?
questions.solution:
Options 2,4 and 5 are correct.

The parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors are:

Lepirudin - renal clearance, contraindicated in renal disease

Argatroban - hepatic clearance, FDA approved for treatment of HIT

Bivalirudin- safe in renal and liver disease, shortest half-life

 

  • Apixaban is a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) which inhibits factor Xa
  • Abciximab is an antiplatelet drug which inhibits Gp IIb-IIIa receptor.

Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). 

Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. Direct thrombin inhibitors and Factor Xa inhibitors are novel oral anticoagulants. Dabigatran is contraindicated in patients with mechanical heart valves.

 

Coagulation profile monitoring :

Lepirudin is a direct irreversible thrombin inhibitor and its most adverse reaction is bleeding. The risk of bleeding can be reduced by implementing an appropriate monitoring and dose adjustment strategy. Thus, coagulation profile monitoring is required for lepirudin.

However, Enoxaparin, Fondaparinux, and Dabigatran do not bind to endothelium or many plasma proteins and thus, the response to these drugs at the usual doses is consistent from patient to patient. Hence, monitoring is not required.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman who is a known diabetic comes with frequent urination, and an increased urge to pass the urine, but passes urine in large quantities before reaching the lavatory. What would be your advice to this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient here is suffering from urge incontinence/overactive bladder due to detrusor muscle instability, therefore bladder training is the appropriate management among the given options, as other options are treatment modalities of stress incontinence.

A patient who suffers from urge incontinence might present with:

  • A patient experiences involuntary escape of urine with the urge to urinate
  • This happens many times during the daytime and may also happen during the night
  • It might also happen during intercourse and just by hearing the sound of water     

Detrusor Instability: Incontinence happens when the detrusor muscle contracts on provocation/spontaneously during the filling phase when inhibition of micturition is attempted. It is mostly caused by parasympathetic overactivity, seen most commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity.

Causes of detrusor instability are functional/psychosomatic, diabetic neuropathy, cerebrovascular accidents, multiple sclerosis, spinal injury, parkinsonism, urinary infection, which can occur following surgeries, etc

Treatment involves low caffeine and nonsmoking, bladder training, restricted fluid intake, and weight reduction. Anticholinergic drugs are useful.

Note: Stress incontinence is usually confused with urge incontinence, in stress incontinence, there is no desire/urge to pass the urine, but passes a small amount of urine during a stressful activity like coughing, sneezing, straining, or physical activity. This is managed with pelvic floor exercises or surgical treatments like sling operations or Kelly's repair.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male was brought by the police under the suspicion of smuggling cocaine in his body. He is found to be asymptomatic and his abdominal X-ray reveals smooth, well-circumscribed foreign bodies measuring approximately 2-3 cm. Which among the following is correct regarding the management of such cases?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 2, and 5 are correct.

The given clinical features are suggestive of this person being a body packer. Since he is asymptomatic, the next step in management would be to give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to gently hasten packet elimination.

CT imaging is the best modality to identify cocaine packets in a body packer. 

  • Body stuffer: Patients who swallow cocaine following police pursuit to conceal the evidence are termed “body stuffers.” The swallowed packets are often poorly wrapped and can leak or perforate.
  • Body packers: swallow a large number of well-sealed packets in order to smuggle drugs across international borders.
  • Both methods can result in severe toxicity and death.
  • CT is the best imaging modality to identify the packets.
  • If the patient shows no signs of toxicity, give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to gently fasten the packet elimination.
  • For symptomatic patients, immediate surgical consultation for operative removal of the packets.
  • Do not go for endoscopy or colonoscopy because any manipulation can rupture the packets.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man underwent an orthopedic procedure following which he was taking multiple antibiotics. He later developed fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis. Pseudomembranous colitis is suspected. The criteria for the diagnosis of the suspected condition includes all except?

choices.text: Detection of toxin A or B in stool
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualise the organism
Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)

questions.solution:
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism is not part of the criteria for the diagnosis of pseudomembranous colitis

Pathologically, the organism produces two toxins; Toxin A(Enterotoxin) causing large-volume diarrhea, and Toxin B(Cytotoxin) causing epithelial injury and bloody stools.

The endoscopic image below shows pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). It is most commonly associated with the use of antimicrobials like cephalosporin, ampicillin, fluoroquinolones, clindamycin, etc.

The diagnosis is based on a combination of 2 criteria:
1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)
2. Detection of toxins A & B in stools, detection of toxin-producing C. difficile by NAAT/Culture, Visualisation of the pseudomembrane in the colon.

questions.text: You are encountering a case at the forensics department where the victim's body had an entry wound from a shotgun as shown below. What is the most likely distance range of the shot?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central rat-hole with peripheral satellite pellet holes appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun. So it was most likely shot at a distance range of 1-5 meters. 

Appearance of shotgun entry wounds at different ranges:

Contact shot

  • Soft tissues -
    • Single circular wound, often with muzzle imprint
    • The diameter of the wound is approximately the same as that of the muzzle.
    • No soot soiling, tattooing, singeing
  • Bone
    • Same as that of soft tissues, but wound may be split and ragged due to gas rebound

<30 cm

  • Circular wound with surrounding soot soiling
  • Burnt hairs - singeing
  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles - tattooing

30 cm to 1 m

  • Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes
  • Soot soiling
  • Powder tattooing

1–5 meters

  • Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes
  • No soot, tattooing +/-

>5 meters

  • Diffuse pellet pattern
  • No central hole, no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing

questions.text: A 23-year-old in the postnatal period after her first delivery developed a uterine prolapse of the level given below. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ring pessaries are the preferred management in the case of prolapse in the postnatal period.

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for 3-4 months, with abdominal exercises, massage, and perineal exercises.  Young women rapidly improve if appropriate conservative methods are employed. If surgery is performed within 6 months of delivery, there is a high chance of recurrence of the prolapse.

The image below shows the various degrees of uterovaginal prolapse.

Various surgeries were performed for the management of uterovaginal prolapse:

  1. Anterior colporrhaphy: This is done for cystocele or cystourethrocele.
  2. Posterior colporrhaphy/ colpoperineorrhaphy: This is done for posterior defects like rectocele or rectal defects with perineal laxity.
  3. Le Forte's repair: This is preferred only in elderly women with advanced prolapse, or those unfit for surgery. Women wanting an active sexual life are poor candidates for this procedure as it creates an adhesive area in the midline.
  4. Abdominal sling surgeries: Young women desirous of retaining menstrual and reproductive functions are ideal candidates. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. These include:
    1. Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre) - sling attached to cervix posteriorly near uterosacral ligaments. 
    2. Shirodkar's sling surgery - the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
    3. Khanna's sling surgery - sling fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament. 
  5. Fothergill surgery (Manchester operation): An anterior colporrhaphy is combined with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are then sutured in front of the cervix followed by a colpoperineorrhaphy. It is suitable for women <40 years desiring reproductive function, but fertility may be reduced.
  6. Ward-Mayo surgery: This is a combination of vaginal hysterectomy + pelvic floor repair. It is done in women >40 years, not desiring reproductive function.
  7. Moschowitz surgery: This is performed for enterocele repair where the pouch of Douglas is obliterated.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was non-compliant with his tuberculosis medication now comes with back pain. You suspect the disease has disseminated to the spine. Which part in the given image of the spine, is most commonly affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient is likely to have developed tuberculosis of the spine. The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine/ Tb spine is the paradiscal type.

The structures marked in the image:

  1. Posterior spinal elements
  2. Paradiscal area of the vertebra
  3. Anterior vertebral body
  4. Central vertebral body

Tb spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbous.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) is affected.

Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine.

questions.text: A 25-year old woman at 32 weeks of gestation with Rh-negative pregnancy undergoes the following analysis. The amniotic fluid bilirubin levels plotted falls in zone 3. Which of the following is/are correct considering the management after this result?
questions.solution:
Options 3, and 4 are correct.

Spectral analysis of amnionic fluid is used to measure bilirubin concentration to plot the modified Liley's chart in Rh-negative pregnancies.

This helps in the estimation of hemolysis severity and indirect assessment of anaemia. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm—ΔOD450.

The chart is divided into 3 zones: 

Liley’s zone I (low zone):

Rh-negative fetus or fetus unlikely to be affected to only mild disease 

Liley’s zone II (mid zone):

Indicates fetal anaemia

Lower zone 2: Hemoglobin concentration of 11 to 13.9 g/dL. 

Upper zone 2: Hemoglobin concentration of 8.0 to 10.9 g/dL.

Liley’s zone III (high zone):

  • The fetus is severely affected and death is imminent.
  • Pregnancy >34 weeks → delivery.
  • Pregnancy <34 weeks → cordocentesis → hematocrit < 30% → intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks

questions.text: A forensic expert wants to analyze the DNA from a semen sample he collected from the crime scene. He uses the following test to amplify and analyze the genetic material. Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding this technique?
questions.solution:
The Polymerase Chain Reaction is shown in the image and it is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA.

Both DNA and RNA can be studied by PCR. It provides a sensitive, selective, and extremely rapid means of amplifying any desired sequence of DNA.

The technique of PCR:

The DNA sample is first heat-denatured at >90°C ( 90-96 degrees Celsius for 3 minutes) to separate the two strands of the template DNA containing the target sequence; the primers ( which attach to the 3' end of the flanking sequence) are added in excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically at 50-75°C) in order to generate the required template-primer complex.

 

 

Related Pearl: Some Enzymes Used in Recombinant DNA Research

Enzymes

Use

Phosphatases

Removal of 5′-PO4 groups prior to kinase labeling; also used to prevent self-ligation

DNA ligase

Joining of DNA molecules

DNA polymerase I

Synthesis of double-stranded cDNA; nick translation; generation of blunt ends from sticky ends

Thermostable DNA polymerases

Polymerase chain reaction (DNA synthesis)

DNAse I

Nick translation; mapping of hypersensitive sites; mapping protein-DNA interactions

Exonuclease III

DNA sequencing; ChIP-exo, mapping of DNA-protein interactions

λ Exonuclease

DNA sequencing

Polynucleotide kinase

32P end-labeling of DNA or RNA

Reverse transcriptase

Synthesis of cDNA from mRNA; RNA (5′ end) mapping studies

RNAse H

Synthesis of cDNA from mRNA

S1 nuclease

Removal of “hairpin” in synthesis of cDNA; RNA mapping studies (both 5′ and 3′ ends)

Terminal transferase

Homopolymer tailing

Recombinases (CRE, INT, FLP)

Generation of specific chimeric DNA molecules, work both in vitro and in vivo

questions.text: A patient with the hearing aid shown in the image below was brought to you in ENT OPD for follow-up. All of the following options represent the indications for this type of hearing aid, except _____.

choices.text: A 7-year-old patient with single-sided hearing loss
A 13-year-old patient with bilateral ear discharge unresponsive to treatment
A 10-year-old patient with bilateral canal atresia
A 20-year-old patient with bilateral acoustic neuroma

questions.solution:
The above image shows bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA), and all the given options are indications for BAHA, except for patients with bilateral acoustic neuroma, as they have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

Bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) is based on the principle of bone conduction. They are used in the following conditions:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal associated with discharge and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids
    • Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia
  • Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis, where surgery is contraindicated
  • Single-sided deafness

BAHA combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear and allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear—a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

  • An innermost titanium fixture in the bone
  • A middle abutment 
  • An outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment

Usually, BAHA is placed posterosuperior to the external auditory canal in the temporal bone.

 

Related Pearl: BAHA (Bone Anchored Hearing Aid)

It replaces the external auditory canal and middle ear and directly stimulates cochlea.

Indications:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment
    • Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment
    • Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid
  • Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated
  • Single-sided hearing loss

Eligibility:

  • Cochlea and nerve should be functional
  • BC threshold should be better than or equal to 45 dB on PTA

Components:

Mechanism of action:

questions.text: A 25-year-old  female was suspected to be suffering from primary Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial Autonomic symptoms (SUNA). Which of the following points are correct in favor of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 2 and 4 are correct.

Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic symptoms(SUNA) or Short- lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing(SUNCT):

It is a primary headache syndrome which is characterized by severe, unilateral temporal/orbital pain which is throbbing/stabbing type. But, the pain can be localised anywhere in the head. Attacks are usually associated with cutaneous triggers, and there is a lack of refractory period to triggering between attacks. It does not respond to indomethacin.

Neurologic examination is normal. Diagnosis requires at least 20 attacks which last for 5-240 s. When associated with lacrimation/ conjunctival injection, it is SUNCT. When lacrimation is missing, it is diagnosed as SUNA.

Management: Acute attacks are of short duration, therefore therapy of acute attacks is not useful. However, IV lidocaine can be used in hospitalised patients.

The goal of treatment is long-term prevention to decrease disability and hospitalization, for which lamotrigine is most effective.

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua
   Cluster headache Paroxysmal hemicrania   SUNCT/SUNA
Gender  Males>females Female=Males Female=Males
Character of pain  Stabbing /boring Throbbing pain /stabbing /boring Burning /stabbing/sharp
Severity of pain  Excruciating  Excruciating Severe to excruciating
Site of pain  Orbit, temple Orbit, temple Periorbital
Attack frequency  1-8 /day 1-20/day 3-200/day
Duration 15min-3 hours 2-30 min 5-240seconds
Migraneous feature  Yes  Yes  Yes
Alcohol trigger  Yes No No
Cutaneous trigger No No Yes
Response to indomethacin No Yes No
Abortive treatment

100% oxygen

Sumatriptan injection

No effective treatment

IV lidocaine 
Prophylaxis

Chronic cluster

  • Lithium
  • Verapamil
  • Methysergide

Episodic cluster 

  • Steroids 
  • Verapamil
  • Methysergide
  • Indomethacin
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Indomethacin is effective in paroxysmal hemicrania,hemicrania continuum, and primary sexual/ exercise headache
  • Cutaneous trigger is also seen in trigeminal neuralgia, however, trigeminal neuralgia is a separate entity and not a part of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the role of Hepcidin in Iron metabolism?

choices.text: Hepcidin activity is low in secondary hemochromatosis
Hepcidin binds to ferritin and inhibits iron transfer
Hepcidin production is increased in chronic diseases
Hepcidin activity is low in  primary  hemochromatosis

questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin (not ferritin).

Hepcidin is released by the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels. It inhibits iron transfer by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are sloughed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Inflammatory cytokines
  • Iron

Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:

  • Iron deficiency
  • Hypoxia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis
  • primary and secondary hemochromatosis

Mutation in hepcidin causes Hereditary hemochromatosis. Secondary hemochromatosis can also occur due to the suppression of hepatic hepcidin production in diseases associated with ineffective erythropoiesis, such as β-thalassemia major and myelodysplastic syndrome.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented with a deformity of the left arm as shown in the below image. It is due to the rupture of the tendon of:

choices.text: Long head of the biceps brachii muscle
Short head of the biceps brachii muscle

questions.solution:
The given image shows Popeye's sign. It occurs due to the rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii muscle.

Popeye sign appears due to the bulging of the muscle belly caused by contraction of the unrestrained muscles on flexing the elbow. The sign is named due to the resemblance of the deformity with the famous cartoon character 'Popeye'.

Biceps brachii is one of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm. It has two heads - a long head and the short head. The long head originates from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula whereas the short head originates from the apex of the coracoid process. Both heads get inserted into the radial tuberosity. 

The biceps brachii muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6). It causes powerful flexion of the forearm at the elbow joint and supination of the forearm. It also is an accessory flexor of the arm at the glenohumeral joint. 

The rupture of muscles and tendons of the upper limb is usually uncommon, however, the long head of biceps brachii is the most commonly ruptured tendon. The distal biceps tendon may also rupture and it is important to determine its exact site, as it will determine the surgical approach for repair. 

The brachialis is also a muscle in the anterior compartment of the arm. It originates from the anterior aspect of the humerus and inserts into the ulnar tuberosity. It is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6) and radial nerve (C7). It is a strong flexor of the forearm at the elbow joint. 

Related Pearl: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb

Key Sensory Areas:

  • C5 - Upper lateral part of arm
  • C6 - Palmar pad of thumb
  • C7 - Pad of index finger
  • C8 - Pad of little finger
  • T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: During the attempted intubation of a patient, the senior resident complains that the glottis is too anterior and asks the junior resident to perform a maneuver so that the senior resident would be able to visualize the glottis better as shown below. Identify the correct sequence of steps that the junior resident would have performed for obtaining such a result.
questions.solution:
The maneuver that the junior resident would have performed is the BURP maneuver, where a Backwards->Upwards->Rightwards pressure is applied externally so as to move an anteriorly positioned glottis posterior for getting better visualization.

You can visualize the step-by-step result of the maneuver in the video below.

Note:

BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A male baby born to a non-consanguineous couple was brought to you with the complaints of severe blistering formed after minor mechanical traumas. You suspect epidermolysis bullosa simplex in this child. Which of the following keratin heterodimers will be affected due to mutation in the genes leading to this condition?
questions.solution:
The mutations in the genes for keratin 5 and 14 are associated with epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS).

Keratin is a complex protein produced by keratinocytes. It is a major component of our hair and nails, and also the stratum corneum of the skin.

Keratin filaments exist as combinations of one acidic and one basic filament.

Note:

Keratin Heterodimer Site
K5/14 Stratum Basale
K1/10 Stratum Spinosum
K3/K12 Cornea- Eye
K4/K13 Buccal Mucosa
K8/18 Simple Epithelium

 

Note: Epidermolysis bullosa is a disorder in which blisters develop in areas of minor trauma. It results from the congenital absence of proteins that help to maintain the structure of the epidermis and also those that connect the dermis and epidermis. There are three types of epidermolysis bullosa-

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex - where the defect is in K5/K14
  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa - where the defect is in Laminin
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa - where the defect is in Collagen-7

Related Pearl: Dermoepidermal Junction/Basement Membrane Zone

  • The junction between epidermis and dermis is called the basement membrane zone or dermoepidermal junction and consists of a number of extracellular macromolecules.
  • As many of these components are glycoproteins, the BMZ can be recognized histologically by staining with PAS stain.
  • Ultrastructural examination by electron microscopy shows 2 different layers with different optical densities
    • Lamina Lucida - upper, less electron dense layer
    • Lamina Densa - lower, more electron dense layer
  • This zone is composed of 3 components : 1. Hemidesmosome 2. Anchoring Filaments 3. Anchoring Fibrils.

1.HEMIDESMOSOME

  • Hemidesmosomes are multiprotein complexes that facilitate the stable adhesion of basal epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.
  • The intermediate keratin filaments K5/K14 present within the basal keratinocytes attach to the hemidesmosomes at the base of the cell.
  • The major hemidesmosomal Protein is Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen-1 (BPAg1 or BP230) and this attaches to the transmembrane component protein BPAg2 (BP180) below.
  • The other hemidesmosomal protein Plectin is attached to the transmembrane component protein called as α6β4 integrin below.

2.ANCHORING FILAMENTS/Lamina Lucida and Lamina Densa

  • The anchoring filaments form the Lamina Lucida layer.
  • Anchoring filaments consist of Laminin5/332 proteins that connect BPAg2 and α6β4 integrin above to Lamina Densa below.
  • Lamina Densa consists mainly of type IV Collagen and other proteins like Nidogen.  

3.ANCHORING FIBRILS

  • These are ultrastructurally U shaped structures that attach the Lamina Densa above to the underlying connective tissue below in dermis.
  • Type VII Collagen is the major protein in anchoring fibrils.

Blistering disorders in the DEJ/BMZ arise due to defects or antibodies against any of the above mentioned proteins.

Image: Gene/protein systems within the cutaneous basement membrane zone that can harbour mutations and result in blistering of the skin in different forms of epidermolysis bullosa (EB). BP, bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: Which of the following options regarding the given pairs of diuretics and their indication is incorrect?

choices.text: Spironolactone - alcoholic patient with cirrhotic ascites
Intravenous mannitol - patient with an acute attack of glaucoma
Acetazolamide - mountaineer with acute mountain sickness
Furosemide - patient with lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

questions.solution:
Amiloride is the most appropriate treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI). Furesemide is contraindicated in the management of lithium induced diabetes insipidus. 

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into renal distal tubule ENaCs and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI. 

Drugs that cause diuresis lead to sodium loss which in turn leads to compensatory Lithium absorption from the proximal tubule, thus leading to toxicity. Hence, furosemide, bumetanide, hydrochlorothiazide and losartan can all cause lithium toxicity

Increased reabsorption of lithium from the proximal tubules is also seen with non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen, naproxen, and possibly aspirin.

Other options:

Spironolactone is used in the treatment of ascites due to cirrhosis. The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone. Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

Acetazolamide is used in the treatment of acute mountain sickness. It is available as an intravenous formulation. It is also indicated in the acute management of open-angle glaucoma for the rapid reduction of IOP.

Intravenous mannitol is used for the treatment of acute attacks of glaucoma. Other indications are:

  • Reduce cerebral edema and intracranial pressure
  • Enhancement of urinary excretion of salicylates, barbiturates, bromides, and lithium
  • For diagnosis of bronchial hyperreactivity (inhalation)
  • Antihemolytic urological irrigation during transurethral procedures

questions.text: Xenodiagnosis is _______________

choices.text: The demonstration of a parasite in the vector following diagnostic infection
The demonstration of a parasite in the reservoir following diagnostic infection
The animal inoculation of a parasite for diagnostic observation
The animal inoculation of a parasite for serological observation

questions.solution:
Xenodiagnosis involves the diagnostic infection of a vector in which the parasite multiplies and can be demonstrated.

For example, in Trypanosoma cruzi, diagnosis may be established by letting the vector reduviid bug feed on suspected patients. After 4-5 weeks, live flagellate forms of Trypanosoma can be seen in the feces of the bugs. In Trichinella spirallis, biopsy bits are fed to laboratory rats, that are killed after a month to demonstrate larvae in the muscles.

Xenodiagnosis can be used in:

  • Wuchereria bancrofti
  • Trypanosoma cruzi
  • Trichinella spiralis

In the case of animal inoculation, Guinea pig or mice inoculation is done with blood, CSF, lymph node aspirate, or any other tissue material. This is a distinct modality, different from using the specific vector of the disease.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is assessing the personality of a patient by using a test with cards containing images. The first card of the set used in this test is similar to the image below. This test is a type of _____.
questions.solution:
The test given is of the Rorschach's inkblot test, which is a projective personality test that measures broad-band personality.

Rorschach's inkblot test:

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase: participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase: participants explain why they formed the impression.

Projective tests:

It is based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a sort of screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Projective tests generally do not measure a particular personality type like 'Type-A personality'(Narrow-band measurement), but rather measures these as a 'whole'(Broad-band measurement)

Commonly used projective tests are:

  • Thematic apperception test
  • Rorschach's inkblot test
  • Sentence completion test
  • Draw a person test

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

 

Sentence Completion Test

Uses Characteristics
Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: One of your patients, who was on enteral nutrition developed refeeding syndrome due to excess feeds given by the attenders. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
All the above metabolic abnormalities will be seen in a patient with refeeding syndrome except Hypoglycemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to:

  • Starvation
  • Alcoholism
  • Delayed nutritional support
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • Massive weight loss in obese patients

With excessive refeeding, there is a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate which stimulates excessive insulin release. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. Hence the metabolic abnormalities include:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypocalcemia

However, severe hyperglycemia may result from blunted basal insulin secretion. These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Treatment includes the correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities. The condition may be prevented by instituting the caloric repletion slowly and gradually increasing it over the first week.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with metastatic ER-positive breast cancer. Tamoxifen therapy was started but the tumor still showed progression. She has been switched to a new drug that acts on the estrogen receptors and has to be taken only once a month. Which of the following is the new drug administered to her?
questions.solution:
Fulvestrant is the new drug administered in this case. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of (estrogen receptor) ER-positive breast cancer, resistant to tamoxifen therapy. 

Fulvestrant is an estrogen antagonist which is indicated in postmenopausal women with hormone-positive breast cancer, which is progressive even after first-line therapy such as tamoxifen.

It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).

It binds to ERα and ERβ with high affinity but represses transactivation. It causes intracellular proteolytic degradation of ERα while protecting ERβ from degradation. This effect on ERα protein levels is responsible for fulvestrant’s efficacy in tamoxifen-resistant breast cancer.

It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated. Nausea, asthenia, and headache are common side effects. It is given as initial biweekly loading doses in the 1st month followed by once-monthly injections. Steady-state levels are achieved in the first month.

Other options:

Option A: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that decreases estrogen synthesis and is widely used now in the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women. Estrogen is locally produced from androgen by the action of the aromatase enzyme. Locally synthesized estrogens play an important role in the development of breast cancer because they are estrogen-dependent for proliferation. 

Options B and C: Selec­tive aromatase inhibitors block the conversion of the hormone androstenedione into estrone by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme. They include:

Reversible aromatase inhibitors:

  • Letrozole (Dose: 2.5 mg Once a day per oral)
  • Anastrozole (Dose: 1 mg Once a day per oral)
  • Vorozole

Irreversible aromatase inhibitors:

  • Exemestane (Dose: 25 mg once a day per oral after meals)
  • Formestane

These agents can also be used as the first-line treatment of breast cancer or as second-line drugs after tamoxifen therapy. They are highly efficacious and superior to tamoxifen in adjuvant use for postmenopausal women. They can either be used following tamoxifen therapy for 2–5 years or as initial agents. They do not increase the risk of uterine cancer or venous thromboemboli.

Related Pearl: Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR-positive cases

Role:

  • Reduce risk of recurrence
  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma
Selective estrogen- receptor modulator Aromatase inhibitors Ovarian suppression/ ablation
  • Tamoxifen
  • Raloxifen
  • Arzoxifen
  • Fenoxifen
  • Anastrazole
  • Letrozole
  • Exemestane
  • Oophorectomy
  • GnRH analogues

questions.text: A bruise on the upper arm of an alleged victim of the assault has the following appearance. What is the age of the injury based on colour of this bruise?
questions.solution:
The bruise in the given image has a yellow appearance which is attributed to the presence of bilirubin. This finding makes the bruise about 7-12 days old.

Bruises are mechanical injuries that are characterized by the extravasation of blood into subcutaneous or subepithelial tissue spaces. The continuity of the overlying skin is preserved. These injuries are typical consequences of blunt force trauma. 

The extravasated blood serves as a sign of inflammation to attract macrophages, which degrade the hemoglobin into various compounds (hemosiderin, haematoidin, and bilirubin). This gives rise to shifting color changes that begin at the wound's periphery and migrate towards the center as time goes on.

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus has been prescribed pioglitazone. What will you tell her when she asks about the most common adverse effect of thiazolidinediones?
questions.solution:
The most common adverse effects of the thiazolidinediones are weight gain and edema.

Thiazolidinediones are a selective agonist of nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ). They modulate the expression of genes involved in lipid and glucose metabolism, insulin signal transduction, and adipocyte differentiation. These effects increase the sensitivity of the tissues to insulin.

Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are used to treat patients with type 2 diabetes. They are known to cause fluid retention and edema and therefore avoided in patients who have heart failure. 

Pioglitazone is metabolized in the liver and constant liver function monitoring is required as it is hepatotoxic. It is thus contraindicated in liver disease.

questions.text: The given image shows a blood agar culture with a bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk. Further testing reveals that this organism is PYR  test- positive. The condition(s) that this organism would produce is/are:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a blood agar culture with a bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin. Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin and PYR test positive. It causes 

  • Erysipelas
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Necrotizing fasciitis  
  • Scarlet fever

Erysipelas is a diffuse infection of superficial lymphatics. The affected skin is red, swollen, and indurated is sharply demarcated from the surrounding healthy area. It is rare and seen in older patients.

Necrotizing fasciitis is characterized by extensive necrosis of subcutaneous and muscular tissues and adjacent fascia. S.pyogenes can be isolated from the affected site It can be associated with a severe systemic illness and toxic shock-like syndrome with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and multiple organ failure. 

Antibodies to the cell wall M antigen present on the Streptococcus cross-reacts with a similar myocardial antigen. This cross-reaction with myocardium is the cause of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Other options: 

Furuncle is caused by Staphylococcus

Beta-hemolytic streptococci were classified by Lancefield based on group-specific carbohydrate C antigen present on the cell wall, into 20 serological types from Group A to Group V except for I and J.

Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are further classified based on protein (M, T, R) antigens present on the cell surface by Griffith typing.

The following table provides important laboratory characteristics which differentiates Streptococcus pyogenes from Streptococcus agalactiae.

Species Lancefield Group Typical Hemolysis Important Lab Characteristics
S. pyogenes A Beta Bacitracin sensitive, PYR test positive
S. agalactiae B Beta Bacitracin resistant, PYR test negative, Hippurate hydrolysis positive, CAMP test positive

  • Vasculitis

  • Kawasaki disease

questions.text: A child born with a rare genetic disorder presented with failure to thrive and susceptibility to recurrent pyogenic, viral, and fungal infections. His blood reports showed lymphopenia and a diagnosis of SCID was suspected. He was advised to stay in a protective 'bubble' as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the disease in question?

choices.text: The X-linked form is due to the deficiency of  adenosine deaminase
Defective humoral and cell-mediated immune responses

questions.solution:
X-linked SCID is the most common form where there is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. The given clinical scenario and the image of a child in a protective bubble (Bubble boy disease) are suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). 

 Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterized by:

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.
  • Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R.

Types of SCID:

X-linked SCID

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

It can be associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ deficiency confers (severe) combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out V(D)J recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Note:

The deficiency of adenosine deaminase enzyme was the first pathophysiologic condition to be treated by gene therapy. In1990, Dr. William French Anderson introduced a new copy of this gene, which was carried on a retroviral vector, into a 4-year-old girl suffering from severe combined immunodeficiency (bubble boy disease).

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

questions.text: You are differentiating the eggs of different parasites by examining samples by wet mount microscopy followed by bile staining . Which of the following parasites will show bile-stained eggs?
questions.solution:
Fasciola hepatica (Sheep liver fluke), Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm) and Trichuris trichiura, (whip worm) will show bile-stained eggs.

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman complained that she was feeling detached from herself. She reported that she felt unreal, empty, and perceived she was watching herself in a movie. Her family says she was raped recently and has not been herself ever since. Which of the following best describes her perception?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of depersonalization. It is defined as the persistent or recurrent feeling of detachment or estrangement from one's self.

The individual may report feeling like watching himself or herself in a movie or feeling like an automaton. Experiences of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer with respect to one's thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions (e.g., perceptual alterations, distorted sense of time, unreal or absent self, emotional and physical numbing).

Derealization refers to feelings of unreality or of being detached from one's environment. The patient may describe his or her perception of the outside world as lacking lucidity and emotional coloring, as though dreaming or dead.

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented to the OPD with fever, dysuria, and frequent micturition. Urine analysis showed pus cells. Gram staining shows gram-negative rods and culture on MacConkey agar shows non-lactose fermenting colonies. The test for the presence of phenylalanine deaminase gives the result shown in the image. Which of the following organisms is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of urinary tract infection, with a gram-negative rod forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar, and the image of a positive phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) reaction are suggestive of Proteus infection.

The phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) reaction is a characteristic feature that distinguishes Proteus from other enterobacteria. All members of the Proteus tribe have the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. Phenyl pyruvic acid imparts a green color. The test is given below:


Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus seen as a normal gastrointestinal flora. The two most common species causing infection in humans are P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris, which can be differentiated by spot indole test. P. mirabilis is indole negative while P. vulgaris is indole positive. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones.

P. mirabilis is associated with urinary tract infections while P. vulgaris is usually associated with wound and soft tissue infections. 

On solid culture media such as blood agar, Proteus shows swarming motility due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar (shown in the image below). However, swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.


Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as:

Lactose fermenters

Escherichia, Klebsiella,Enterobacter 

Late lactose fermenters

Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia

Non-lactose fermenters

Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus

Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPY PSM

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Shigella (Except S Sonnie which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

Other options:

Klebsiella (Option A) and Enterobacter (Option D) are lactose-fermenters on MacConkey's medium. Serratia (Option C) is a late lactose fermenter.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes

questions.text: A 40 -year-old patient came with deformities, swellings, and pain in multiple areas of the limbs, her X-rays of the hands are given below. On examination, her skin doesn't have any hemangiomas. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows multiple tumors affecting the bones of the hand with soft tissue swellings and calcification which is suggestive of multiple enchondromatosis. Multiple enchondromas when present without hemangiomas is called Ollier disease. 

Enchondromas are benign bone tumors of hyaline cartilage which arise from the medullary canal.

Ollier disease is a rare condition in which many cartilaginous tumors appear in the large and small tubular bones and in the flat bones. It is caused by the failure of normal endochondral ossification.

Note: Enchondromatosis with hemangioma of the overlying soft tissue constitutes Maffucci’s syndrome.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents to you with multiple joint pains. On examination, you notice the following deformity over the ring and little finger. This deformity is called:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The is showing hyperextension of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and flexion at proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints suggestive of Boutonniere deformity.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of symmetric polyarthritis, mainly affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. The wrists and metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are most frequently involved. Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness lasting >1 hour that relieves with activity.

A Boutonniere deformity occurs due to the rupture of the central slip of the extensor tendon. Normally, the central slip of the extensor tendon inserts into the base of the middle phalanx. Following rupture of the central slip, the lateral slips also separate creating a gap. The head of the proximal phalanx goes through the gap, resembling a button going through a buttonhole.

The image below shows the two most common deformities in RA.

Being a systemic disease, RA causes various extra-articular manifestations, like subcutaneous nodules, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and anemia of chronic disease.

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate), and CRP (C reactive protein). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis. Progression of joint damage is assessed by plain X-ray.

Management includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), glucocorticoids, and DMARDs (disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs) like methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, leflunomide. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, abatacept, anakinra, rituximab, and interleukin -6 inhibitors are also helpful in RA.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

 

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Spine involvement Cervical spine
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female singer presents to you with weakness of voice after having multiple recordings in the studio. You diagnose phonasthenia in this patient as her indirect laryngoscopy shows the following characteristic finding. This appearance of the glottis is due to the weakness of which of the following muscles.
questions.solution:
The weakness of both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoids gives characteristic Key-hole appearance of the glottis, which is seen in indirect laryngoscopy.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. It is seen in abuse or misuse of voice or following laryngitis.

The weakness of muscles leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

  • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
  • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
  • Both thyroarytenoid & inter arytenoid: Keyhole appearance.

Treatment is voice rest and vocal hygiene

Note: Spasms of posterior cricoarytenoid muscle cause abductor dysphonia

 

Above image shows appearances of glottis in phonasthenia. (A) Weakness of thyroarytenoid. (B) Interarytenoid. (C) Thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, who has completed her family asks for long term contraception, as she usually forgets taking pills as per schedule. She prefers to avoid frequent visits to the hospital and is not willing for surgery. Her previous ultrasound records reveal that she has large fibroids distorting her uterine cavity. What would be the most appropriate contraception amongst the following in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The appropriate contraception for her is Norplant.

As the patient has large fibriods distorting the uterine cavity, IUCDs are not appropriate. The patient is also non-complaint with oral pills, therefore progesterone-only pills are not suitable in her case. Since she needs long term contraception, and prefers to avoid frequent visits to the hospital, depot injections are not feasible as these injections are to be taken every 3 months, whereas implants like norplant are long term and work for 3-5 years.

Norplant I  contains six silastic capsules - has been withdrawn and replaced.

Norplant II (Jadelle) consists of two rods each containing 70 mg LNG. The daily release of hormone is 50 mcg and provides contraception for 3–5 years. Implants mainly suppress the endometrium, but it can also suppress ovulation in about 50%.

Insertion: The implants need to be generally inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, or 3 weeks after the delivery. They will need to use other forms of contraception like barrier methods until 7 days of insertion of implants. It is inserted under local anesthesia and needs removal at the end of its use.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with good effect, therefore compliance is also good.
  • Coital-independent with no need to remember taking pills or getting regular injections.
  • Pregnancy rate—varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, amenorrhoea 
  • Ectopic pregnancy is seen in 1.3%
  • Local infection
  • Requires insertion and removal with minor surgical procedures
  • The implants are expensive

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: While converting a circular incision made for the excision of a skin lesion into an ellipse, what should be the ideal length: width ratio of an elliptical incision for the wound to heal without tension?
questions.solution:
While converting a circular incision made for the excision of a skin lesion into an ellipse, the ratio of length: width ratio of an elliptical incision should be 3:1 for the wound to heal without tension.

This rule of thumb is especially useful when such circular incisions have to be made in regions where the direction of Langer's lines is not apparent. Once the circular incision is made, the wound reveals the lines of tension as the circular incision gets pulled into an ellipse by the tension present. Once the direction becomes evident from this, the circular incision should formally be converted into an ellipse using the above rule of thumb.

If 'dog ears' remain at the ends of an elliptical wound, they should be picked up with a skin hook and excised to obtain a better cosmetic outlook.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with anhidrosis and enophthalmos. Examination reveals miosis along with mild ptosis. You decide to correct the ptosis by performing a Fasanella-Servat operation, by resecting which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome and the associated mild ptosis in this condition can be corrected by resecting Muller's muscle.

Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the paralysis of Muller's muscle.

Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated in cases having mild ptosis(< 2 mm) and good levator function. In this surgery, the upper tarsal border along with its attached Muller’s muscle and conjunctiva are resected.

Related Pearl: Surgical treatment of different types of ptosis

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male who has been on treatment for his arrhythmia came to the OPD for bluish-gray discoloration on the nose, forehead, and cheeks. Which of the following drugs also belong to the same class as the antiarrhythmic drug implicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Options 4 and 5 are correct.

Blue-gray skin discoloration is a side effect of class III antiarrhythmic drug amiodarone. Sotalol and Ibutilide also belong to this class which acts by blocking K+ channels.

Amiodarone is known to cause cutaneous and systemic side effects with the most common cutaneous side effect being photosensitivity. Blue-gray discoloration occurs in body areas when exposed to sunlight. The disappearance of amiodarone-related skin discoloration may occur within months or years.

Apart from the cessation of treatment, avoiding exposure to sunlight and using a sunscreen cream against both ultraviolet-A (UV-A) and UV-B radiation is recommended.

Adverse effects of amiodarone:

  • RS: Interstitial lung disease
  • CVS: Torsades de pointes, heart block, bradycardia, QT prolongation
  • Hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism
  • GI upset, hepatitis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Corneal micro-deposits, optic neuropathy
  • Blue-gray skin coloration

questions.text: "Deficits are more severe for information that was most recently learned." This applies best to:
questions.solution:
"Deficits are more severe for information that was most recently learned" - is known as Ribot's law. This applies best to retrograde amnesia.

Ribot's Law states that "Deficits are more severe for information that was most recently learned," i.e.,  during incidents of retrograde amnesia, recent memories are more likely to be lost than remote memories. Ex:- If an incident causing retrograde amnesia occurs at 30 years of age, the memories acquired at 28 years of age may be more severely affected than those memories acquired at 20 years of age or earlier.

Dissociative amnesia is characterized by extensive and severe amnesia with an inability to recall important autobiographical information. The amnesia is predominantly retrograde with minimal anterograde amnesia. It usually follows severe emotional trauma, interpersonal conflicts, and other stressful events, such as sexual abuse, loss of a loved one, loss of livelihood, etcetera. Clinically, the presentation is quite dramatic with significant impairment in social, personal, and occupational functioning. In order for a diagnosis of dissociative amnesia to be made, it is imperative to rule out substance use, and other neurological and psychological conditions that may lead to a presentation similar to dissociative amnesia. 

It is further categorized into the following types:

  • Selective amnesia: Ability to remember some, but not all of the events occurring during a circumscribed period of time.
  • Localized amnesia: Inability to recall all events in a circumscribed period of time.
  • Generalized amnesia: Failure to recall one’s entire life.
  • Continuous amnesia: Failure to recall successive events as they occur.
  • Systematized amnesia: Amnesia for certain categories of memory, such as all memories relating to one’s family or to a particular person.

Dissociative fugue is characterized by a sudden, unintended, and unexpected travel to a place away from home, or workplace, or another place involved in one's daily repertoire. It is usually brief, lasting few hours to days, and is generally reversible. It is commonly associated with dissociative amnesia. In addition to amnesia, these patients may also experience confusion, trance-like behaviors, depersonalization, derealization, and conversion symptoms. It may recur in some patients.

It is important to note that dissociative fugue was deleted as a major diagnostic category in DSM-5. It is instead declared as a subtype or specifier of disso­ciative amnesia.

Treatment of dissociative amnesia and dissociative fugue is mainly with psychotherapy.

questions.text: An autopsy is done on a plastic factory worker. The gross specimen of the liver is shown in the image below. Reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) are present. The asterisk marks the normal liver tissue. Which of the following compounds is most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of the involved tumor?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) which are seen with hepatic angiosarcoma. Exposure to polyvinyl chloride, arsenic, and thorotrast can lead to this condition.

Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that has equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. They are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.

Hepatic angiosarcomas are associated with exposure to carcinogens.

Examples of carcinogenic agents:

  • Arsenic - in pesticides
  • Thorotrast - a radioactive contrast agent formerly used for radiologic imaging
  • Polyvinyl chloride - a widely used plastic

Hepatic tumors and associated agents

Carcinoma

Carcinogens

Hepatocellular adenoma

Oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids

Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Alcohol, thorotrast

Cholangiocarcinoma

Thorotrast

Angiosarcoma

Thorotrast, vinyl chloride, Arsenic

The given histopathological image shows abundant small blood vessels lined by large atypical endothelial cells and atypical mitoses seen in angiosarcoma. The endothelial origin of these tumors can be demonstrated by immunohistochemical staining for CD31 or von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old non-alcoholic patient gives consent to undergo bariatric surgery as there was a failure of dietary therapy. His BMI  was found to be 41 kg/m2. After a thorough evaluation of the patient, you perform the following bariatric surgery as shown in the below image. Advantages of this procedure include:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of sleeve gastrectomy with the resection of most of the greater curvature. Sleeve gastrectomy is primarily a restrictive type of bariatric surgery. It has become the primary procedure for bariatric surgery in recent years.

Advantages of this procedure:

  • Less challenging procedure
  • Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping)
  • No need for serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding)
  • Reduction in the incidence of internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass)
  • Suitable for patients with preexisting vitamin disorders. Because Preservation of the entire small bowel reduces the risk of vitamin deficiencies.

Other options:

3-year percentage of diabetes remission was seen in sleeve gastrectomy is 50 % and it is least with Gastric band procedure (20%).

Patients who have longstanding severe GERD may not be good candidates for this procedure as GERD is worsened by the anatomical configuration of the sleeve gastrectomy. Barrett’s esophagus is also a contraindication for performing this procedure.

Complications of sleeve gastrectomy includes:

  • Bleed from the staple line
  • Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with weight loss, fatigue, postural hypotension, and hyperpigmentation. Blood tests reveal hyponatremia, and a short cosyntropin test establishes the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following other findings in the tests will suggest, primary adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Options 2, 4, and 5 are correct.

The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is established by the Short Cosyntropin Stimulation Test.

Determination of the level of Plasma ACTH, Renin and Aldosterone is implemented for the differential diagnosis of Primary and Secondary Adrenal Insufficiency

The flowchart below illustrates the diagnosis of Adrenal Insufficiency:

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: An infant was brought to the hospital for routine vaccination. Looking into the records of the baby reveals that the baby has had an allergic reaction to neomycin. Which of the following vaccines should be used with caution in this child because of this history?

choices.text: All the above vaccines can be given safely

questions.solution:
Neomycin is found in traces in vaccines like MMR and IPV, therefore it should be used with caution in patients who are allergic to neomycin, and they should be monitored closely after vaccination so that any allergic reaction can be treated.

Note: Antibiotics are used, usually during vaccine manufacture to prevent bacterial contamination of tissue culture cells in which viruses are grown.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male has an ACL injury and has difficulty walking down the stairs. But he requests a doctor to issue a medical certificate, certifying him as medically fit for a security job. The doctor can be charged under which section of the IPC if he issues a false certificate in this case?
questions.solution:
The punishment for issuing or signing a false certificate is dealt with under IPC 197.
