questions.text: A radiation oncologist uses radiotherapy as part of the treatment protocol for various tumors. This treatment modality is found to be least effective in which among the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is least effective in melanoma as it is a highly radioresistant tumor.

Apoptosis occurs in response to radiation in some but not all cells. No meaningful apoptosis occurs in very radioresistant tumors like melanoma and glioblastoma.

Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and hence radiotherapy is commonly used for treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: You diagnose Ritter disease in a 3‐month‐old child showing widespread peeling and erosion as shown in the below image. Which of the following statement is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) is known as Ritter disease in children.

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome is an exfoliative dermatosis caused by Exfoliative toxins A and B released by Staphylococcus. The toxin ruptures desmosomes primarily in the epidermis as its target is Desmoglein 1.

  • Lack of expression of desmoglein 1 in mucosal regions, its involvement does not occur in this condition. 
  • Children (under the age of 6 years) and neonates are most commonly affected by the generalized form of SSSS, rarely adults may be affected. This is due to less efficient metabolism and excretion of the toxin in neonates/children.
  • Patients usually develop fever and skin tenderness following staphylococcal infection and a widespread erythematous eruption is seen more in flexures which ultimately leads to painful raw areas.
  • Histological examination shows a number of epithelial cells with large nuclei but no inflammatory cells are seen.
  • Splitting of the epidermis is present between the granular and spinous layers.
  • Nikolsky sign is positive i.e dislodgement of the intact superficial epidermis by a shearing force, indicating a plane of cleavage.
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome usually settles within a few weeks when treated with appropriate systemic antibiotics.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to you with the blurring of vision and asthenopia. Below image shows the type of refractive error seen in this patient. You diagnose astigmatism and prescribe him with an appropriate cylindrical lens. Identify the true statements regarding astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Options 3 and 5 are true regarding astigmatism.

Astigmatism is a type of refractive error in which the eye does not focus light evenly on the retina. This results in a distorted or blurred vision. Other symptoms include eyestrain or asthenopia with headaches.

Types:

  • Regular astigmatism: In this refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another resulting in 2 principal meridians
  • Iregular astigmatism: It is characterized by an irregular change of refractive power in different meridians and hence it has multiple meridians.

Types of regular astigmatism:

With the rule astigmatism: The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal meridian but they are placed at right angles to one another

Against-the-rule astigmatism: Here Horizontal meridians is more curved than the vertical meridian

Oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians although they are at right angles to each other. It is a type of regular astigmatism. eg : one may be at 45 degrees and the other at 135 degrees.

Bioblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other, at 100 degrees. It is also a type of regular astigmatism.

 

 

Note: Refractive types of regular astigmatism:

  • Simple astigmatism: rays are focused on the retina in one meridian: either in front (simple myopic as shown in the above image) of the retina or behind the retina (simple hyperopic)
  • Compound astigmatism: rays in both the meridia are focused in front or behind the retina
  • Mixed astigmatism: Light rays in one meridian are focused in front of the retina and those in the other meridian are focused behind the retina.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presented with weakness, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. On examination, massive splenomegaly is present. Investigations reveal pancytopenia and his peripheral blood smear is as shown below. Which of the following treatment options will be correct to consider for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
According to the clinical scenario given above and the presence of Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear shown in the image, the most likely diagnosis is Hairy cell leukaemia. 

Hairy cell leukaemia is due to clonal proliferation of B-cell lymphocytes. They appear as cells with oval nuclei, abundant cytoplasm, and distinctive membrane projections (hairy cells). Most patients present with symptoms of cytopenias or splenomegaly. The most common physical finding in hairy cell leukemia is splenomegaly. Patients are typically males in their 50s. Dry tap is obtained upon performing bone marrow aspiration due to HCL-induced marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells.

CD11c, CD25, CD103 is the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic of Hairy cell leukaemia. Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 can also test positive for Hairy cell leukemia.

Diagnosis: Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukaemia from other B cell malignancies.

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool in the clinical diagnosis of hairy cell leukaemia and yields positive results in ≈95% of the cases.

Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear is an important diagnostic finding. However, these can be seen in other B-cell disorders also.

Typical hairy cells (shown below) are mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections.

Note: 

  • Splenic marginal zone lymphoma involves both white pulp and red pulp of the spleen (Hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp)
  • All Non-Hodgkin's lymphomas involve the white pulp of the spleen except:
    • Hairy cell leukaemia
    • Hepatosplenic lymphoma

The pattern of bone marrow involvement on biopsy specimens is near to pathognomonic for hairy cell leukemia (>99%).

  • Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with “honeycomb” appearance.
  • Individual cells have a "fried egg" appearance such that the nucleus of each hairy cell is surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm.

Treatment: 

Cladribine is the first line therapy for hairy cell leukemia.

It is a purine analogue and antineoplastic agent used primarily in the therapy of hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine and deoxycoformycin are highly active agents and cause durable remissions in patients. The major side effect is immunosuppression.

Interferon-alpha is also used but not as effective as nucleoside analogues. 

Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remissions.

Chemotherapy-refractory patients are treated with vemurafenib, a BRAF kinase inhibitor.

questions.text: Identify the origin of the  marked structure "1":
questions.solution:
The marked structure "1" is Rectus femoris and it originates from Anterior inferior iliac spine.

Rectus femoris origin:

  • Straight head originates from the anterior inferior iliac spine
  • Reflected head originates from the ilium just superior to the acetabulum

Unlike the vastus muscles, which cross only the knee joint, the rectus femoris muscle crosses both the hip and the knee joints.

 Rectus femoris performs extension at the knee and flexion at the hip. All other quadriceps perform only extension at the knee.

questions.text:
Which of the following are mechanisms of action of dapsone?
  1. Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase
  2. Inhibits neutrophil myeloperoxidase
  3. Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR)
  4. Inhibits neutrophil migration
  5. Inhibits thymidylate synthase
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of dapsone includes:

  1. Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase
  2. Inhibition of neutrophil myeloperoxidase
  3. Inhibition of neutrophil migration

Dapsone is a structural analogue of PABA and competitively inhibits dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway.

The anti-inflammatory effects of dapsone occur due to the inhibition of:

  1. Tissue damage by neutrophils
  2. Neutrophil myeloperoxidase activity and respiratory burst
  3. Migration of neutrophils to inflammatory lesions

Dapsone may also act as a neutrophil-free-radical scavenger.

Dapsone is used in the treatment of leprosy, malaria, P. jiroveci infection, and toxoplasma prophylaxis. Its anti-inflammatory property is the basis for the treatment of pemphigoid, dermatitis herpetiformis, linear IgA bullous disease, etc.

Adverse effects include hemolysis at doses of 200-300mg and methemoglobinemia.

Note: Dapsone does not cause inhibition of DHFR or thymidylate synthase. Methotrexate and pemetrexed are dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors. 5-Fluorouracil (5FU) and capecitabine are thymidylate synthase inhibitors.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer from Eastern UP presented to the local PHC with a scrotal swelling and edema of the right leg. Suspecting filariasis, he was subjected to the DEC Provocation test.  Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this test?

choices.text: 100 mg of DEC is administered orally
Can be done during the day time
This test is cumbersome for surveys
Blood collected in 20-50 minutes will show microfilariae

questions.solution:
DEC provocation test has a great advantage for surveys as blood collected 20-50 minutes after the DEC administration will show microfilariae and the blood collection can be done during daytime. DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria in Wuchereria bancrofti infection.

Diethylcarbamazine is administered as 100 mg or 2 mg/kg body weight orally. This causes the mobilization of microfilariae into the peripheral blood and thus detection of microfilariae by the collection of a sample of peripheral blood.

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial nematode that causes lymphatic filariasis. The adult worms reside in the lymphatics and mechanical obstruction by the adult worms or allergic inflammatory reaction to worm antigens is responsible for the clinical manifestations of lymphatic filariasis. 

The microfilaria, on the other hand, are present in the blood of humans where they demonstrate nocturnal periodicity, wherein the microfilaria appear in the peripheral blood only during nighttime and migrate to vessels of the lung or kidneys during the day time. Hence a sample of peripheral blood for identification of the microfilariae is collected during the nighttime, between 10 pm to 4 am.

On microscopy, these microfilariae have sheathed bodies with blunt heads and pointed tails. They have no nuclei at their tail tip. These features can help in distinguishing the microfilaria of Wuchereria from those of other filarial nematodes.

Detection of microfilariae is done by examination of a thick and thin blood smear, stained with Giemsa stain. Examination of the unstained mount of blood under a microscope using an acridine-orange microhematocrit tube technique can also be done. Detection of the adult worm is done by lymph node biopsy, X-ray (if worms are calcified), and high-frequency ultrasound Doppler of the scrotum.

Indirect evidence includes eosinophilia in blood and elevated serum IgE levels. Immunodiagnosis involves antigen detection by ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) and ICT (immunochromatographic test). Antibody detection tests have low sensitivity and specificity. Molecular diagnosis is done by PCR (polymerase chain reaction). This test is positive only when microfilariae are present in peripheral blood. It is negative in chronic filariasis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. The life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti is given below:

questions.text: A young rape victim is brought for a medical examination. After taking consent, you collect the specimens from the victim to send for investigations. Which of the following will provide you with the absolute proof of the presence of semen?
questions.solution:
Options 3 and 5 are correct.

Electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection and presence of at least one unbroken spermatozoan are indicative of absolute proof of the presence of semen. Sperm identification should not be done only on the basis of the sperm head.

The sperm-specific lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzyme separated from other LDH isoenzymes of semen by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis is suitable for differentiation of human semen from other human body fluids and semen of other animals.

Precipitin test - Specific antiserum is made to react with the seminal fluid, blood or saliva. A positive test will confirm human origin.

An acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains. The semen contains acid phosphatase from the prostatic secretions. Recovered semen  retains its concentrations up to 36 hours after it's deposition. This test can be used conclusively in cases of Aspermia or in cases of the absence of demonstrable sperms.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use the same second messenger system as the drug of choice for the treatment of PPH?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin is the drug of choice for the treatment of PPH and it uses the Phospholipase C Second Messenger System.

Parathyroid hormone, Gonadotropin-releasing hormone, and Angiotensin II act via the same second messenger system. 

Secretin and Somatostatin act via the Adenylyl Cyclase–cAMP Second Messenger System

1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: The plain X-ray of the erect abdomen of a 30-year-old male, who came with complaints of acute abdominal pain and distension is shown in the below image. All of the following radiological signs can be seen in the given condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray images are suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. All the given signs are seen in this except spinnaker-sail sign.

The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails.

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Rigler's sign, telltale triangle sign, falciform ligament sign are the radiological findings seen in supine abdominal x-ray.

The above image shows:

  • Oval lucency seen on supine film, divided by the falciform ligament resulting in the so-called football sign in a neonate with a large pneumoperitoneum. 

The supine abdominal radiograph of the patient showing the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with movement disorder is being evaluated.  You suspect subcortical dementia. Which of the following can be causes for this?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 3 and 5 are true.

 Subcortical dementia:

It involves the thalamus, basal ganglia, cerebellum, and brain stem.

Causes:

  • Parkinson's disease
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • normal pressure hydrocephalus,
  • vascular dementia
  • Huntington's disease
  • Wilson's disease
  • Idiopathic basal ganglia calcification

Examples of cortical dementia:

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Frontotemporal dementia/Picks disease
  • Creutzfeldt Jakob disease

Differences between cortical and subcortical dementia:

  Cortical dementia   Subcortical dementia
Site of lesion  Cortex Thalamus, basal ganglia, cerebellum, brain stem

Aphasia

Apraxia

Agnosia

Prosopagnosia

Acalculia

Ataxia

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy returned from a birthday party and began vomiting 4-5 hours later, followed by a few episodes of loose stools, but had no fever. Other children who had attended the party reported a similar illness. Food samples were collected and sent for toxin detection by a test based on the following principle. This test is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Sandwich ELISA. The above clinical scenario is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

The symptoms of food poisoning caused by S aureus appear within 1-8 hours. Multiple people are exposed to the pathogen from a common source and present with vomiting, loose stools but no fever. Foods from outbreaks of food poisoning is examined for the presence of staphylococcal enterotoxin A (SEA) by a sandwich ELISA.

ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) involves the use of an immunosorbent, which is an absorbing material that is specific for one of the components of the reaction, either the antigen or antibody. This may be a particulate phase (cellulose or agarose), or a solid phase (polystyrene, polyvinyl, or polycarbonate tubes or microwells). ELISA is done using 96-well microtitre plates suitable for automation.

Sandwich ELISA is used for antigen detection in the patient samples. The antigen is sandwiched between two layers of antibodies - capture and detection antibodies.

The following steps are followed in Sandwich ELISA:

  1. The capture antibody is immobilized on a microtiter well.
  2. A sample containing antigen is added and allowed to react with the immobilized antibody.
  3. After the well is washed, a second enzyme-linked antibody (Detecting antibody) specific to the antigen is added and allowed to react with the bound antigen.
  4. After any free second antibody is removed by washing, the substrate is added. This substrate is converted by the enzyme to detectable colored form and the colored reaction product is measured.

Other options:

Option A: Cassette ELISA: Here, each specimen is tested in a separate disposable cassette and gives rapid results (10-15 minutes). There is no need for microplate washers or readers and the result can be read visually. Example: Dot Blot Assay used for the detection of HIV type 1 and 2 antibodies.

Option C: Competitive ELISA: Both the unknown antigen (sample) and the known antigen (standard) compete with each other for a fixed amount of antibody.

Option D: Indirect ELISA: Antibody in the sample can be detected or quantitatively measured using this method. Serum or some other sample containing primary antibody (Ab1) is added to an antigen-coated microtiter well and allowed to react. Enzyme-conjugated secondary anti-isotype antibody (Ab2) is added which binds to the primary antibody.

The given image shows steps followed in different types of ELISA.

questions.text: While evaluating a glaucoma patient,  You notice Schwalbe's line,  trabecular meshwork, and scleral spur by gonioscopic examination. What is the gonioscopic grading of the angle width in this patient according to Shaffer’s system?
questions.solution:
According to Shaffer’s system, The given can be belongs to grade 3 as Schwalbe's line, trabecular meshwork, and scleral spur can be visualized by gonioscopic examination.

The angle of the anterior chamber plays an important role in the process of aqueous drainage. It is formed by,

  • Schwalbe’s line (SL)
  • Trabecular meshwork (TM)
  • Scleral spur (SS),
  • Anterior part Ciliary body (CB),
  • Root of the iris.

Clinically, these structures can be visualized by gonioscopic examination.

Shaffer’s system is most commonly used for Gonioscopic grading of the angle width.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented to you with white growth over the cornea as shown in the image. Identify the true statements regarding this condition:
questions.solution:
In the given image we can see a triangular/wing-shaped encroachment of conjunctiva on the cornea suggestive of Pterygium. Options 1 and 3 are true with respect to this condition.

Pterygium:

  • It is a triangular encroachment of the vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.
  • Pathologically it is a degenerative and hyperplastic condition of conjunctiva.
  • The vascularized granulation tissue invades the cornea, destroying the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman's membrane.
  • It may be unilateral or bilateral but Usually present on the nasal side but may also occur on the temporal side
  • Probe test helps to differentiate pterygium from pseudopterygium. Probe test is negative in pterygium i.e Probe cannot be passed underneath the pterygium.
  • Treatment includes surgical excision.

Note: Regressive type is a thin, atrophic, attenuated pterygium with very little vascularity. Stocker’s line is the deposition of iron may be seen just anterior to the head of the pterygium.

questions.text: The mammalian nuclear DNA-Dependent RNA Polymerase III has the following properties_____
questions.solution:
The mammalian DNA-Dependent RNA Polymerase III shows intermediate sensitivity to α-Amanitin. tRNA, 5s rRNA, and some snRNAs are the major products synthesized by this enzyme.

α-amanitin is an inhibitor of RNA polymerase in eukaryotes. α-amanitin is a potent toxin produced by the poisonous mushroom Amanita phalloides (sometimes called “death cap”). RNA polymerase II shows maximum sensitivity to α-amanitin. α-Amanitin forms a tight complex with the polymerase, thereby inhibiting mRNA synthesis and, ultimately, protein synthesis.

Rifampicin inhibits the prokaryotic DNA dependent RNA polymerase and not the eukaryotic RNA polymerase.

Form of RNA Polymerase Sensitivity to α-Amanitin Major Products Synthesized
I  Insensitive rRNA
II  High sensitivity  mRNA, lncRNA, miRNA, snRNA
III Intermediate sensitivity tRNA, 5s rRNA, some snRNAs

questions.text: The given structure of brachial plexus is marked(X) during an anatomy practical exam and students were asked to list out its branches, they will consist of:
questions.solution:
The pointed structure is the posterior cord, as it is formed by the posterior divisions of the superior/upper, middle and inferior/lower trunk. The thoracodorsal nerve, axillary nerve and subscapular nerve are its branches from the given options.

Branches of the posterior cord are:

  • Upper Subscapular nerve (C5,C6)
  • Thoracodorsal nerve (C6-C8)
  • Axillary (C5,C6)
  • Radial (C5-T1)
  • Lower Subscapular (C5,C6)

questions.text: A person working in a radiology lab is at risk of developing harmful effects of radiation. Which of the following are the stochastic effects of radiation seen in them?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Heritable mutations and Secondary malignancies are the stochastic effects.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: Stochastic effects and nonstochastic/deterministic effects

Stochastic effects(chance or random effects): These effects of ionizing radiation are chance events, with the probability of the effect increasing with dose, but the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received.(All or none phenomenon)

Stochastic effects are assumed to have no threshold. These effects are associated with damage to the DNA of cells.

Examples include secondary malignancies and heritable mutations.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects (non-random effects): These effects are related directly to the absorbed radiation dose and the severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. 

A deterministic effect typically has a threshold below which the effect does not occur. These effects are associated with radiation-induced killing or malfunction of cells.

Radiation-induced skin erythema, lens opacification, and transient decrease in sperm count are a few examples of nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man who is a smoker for the past 2 decades is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. The tumor is located in the periphery of the lung and CT-guided biopsy reveals the following histopathology. Markers such as synaptophysin and CD56 are positive. Which of the following is not classically seen in this patient?

choices.text: Immunohistochemistry showing high levels of  BCL2 protein
Hyponatremia  due to inappropriate ADH secretion can be seen
Preinvasive phase is commonly seen in major bronchi
Cushing Syndrome due to ACTH production can be seen

questions.solution:
There is no known preinvasive phase seen in small cell carcinoma of the lung. This patient's clinical features and the histological image showing the basophilic staining of the vessel wall (Azzopardi effect) are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing Syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion.A majority of small-cell carcinomas (90%) show high levels of antiapoptotic BCL2 protein on Immunohistochemistry.

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who is under the support of a mechanical ventilator in ICU is found to be improving and is planned to be weaned off from ventilatory support. As an anesthetist, you plan to give spontaneous breathing trials using a T-piece. All of the following is a pre-requisite for weaning off except

choices.text: Vital capacity >10 ml/ kg body weight

questions.solution:
Rapid shallow breathing index should be < 105 to wean off a patient from a mechanical ventilator.

Tidal volume is kept ideally at 4-6 ml/kg body weight. A value more than this will cause lung injury.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when he can breathe spontaneously and is hemodynamically stable with adequate arterial oxygen saturation.

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10 L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <105

Note: Patients with an RSBI of less than 105 can be successfully extubated. Those with an RSBI greater than 120 should retain mechanical ventilator support.

Related Pearl: Mechanical Criteria for Weaning or Extubation

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20 to -30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: 10L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index: <100

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and flank pain. You suspect renal cystic mass and advise CT.  Based on CT findings, the renal cystic mass has been classified as category IIF according to the  Bosniak classification system. What will be the management in this case?
questions.solution:
Management of Renal cysts classified under Bosniak category IIF require follow up by imaging.

The Bosniak classification system of renal cystic masses is helpful in predicting the risks of malignancy and identifying the appropriate choice of treatment. It includes,

Classification:

Bosniak 1

  • Simple cyst: Not malignant, imperceptible wall, rounded,
  • No further workup required

Bosniak 2

  • Minimally complex: Not malignant, septa <1mm, thin calcifications, renal lesions <3 cm.
  • No further workup required.

Bosniak 2F

  • Percentage malignant: ~ 5% 
  • Minimally complex: increased number of septa, minimally thickened with nodular or thick calcifications
  • Follow-up: Needs ultrasound/CT follow up - in about 6 months

Bosniak 3

  • Indeterminate
  • Percentage malignant: ~55%
  • Thick, nodular multiple septa or wall with measurable enhancement, hyperdense on CT.
  • Treatment/work-up: Partial nephrectomy or radiofrequency ablation in elderly or poor surgical candidates.

Bosniak 4

  • Clearly malignant (100%)
  • Treatment: Partial or total nephrectomy
  • Solid mass with a large cystic or necrotic component

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been bitten by a wild dog resulting in a category III wound. He has a record of previous complete pre-exposure vaccination against rabies that he had taken 6 months back. Which of the following are indicated in this person?
questions.solution:
For a rabies-exposed person who has documentation of previous complete rabies vaccination(>3 months old), a booster dose of IM/ID vaccination is sufficient on days 0 and 3.

Rabies immunoglobulin is not indicated in such cases. 

Proper wound care is essential in all dog bite cases. Washing with soap and water followed by application of antiseptic agent (Any virucidal agent like povidone-iodine, alcohol etc) is to be done.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gunstock deformity of his hand which developed after he sustained a fracture. On examination, you notice that he was unable to perform the following sign and there were no associated sensory symptoms. This is suggestive of:

choices.text: Injury to the deep branch of ulnar nerve
Injury to the superficial branch of ulnar nerve
Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve
Injury to the anterior interosseous nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of gun stock deformity following a fracture indicates a history of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The sign shown in the above image is the 'OK sign' and the inability to perform this sign is suggestive of injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a purely motor branch of the median nerve. 

In the case of supracondylar fracture, the most common nerve injuries: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve

The patient is asked to perform the OK sign by touching the tips of the index finger and the thumb. Normally, the patient is able to flex the distal phalanges, producing an O-shape. 

In anterior interosseous nerve injury (AIN), the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus are weak. The patient is unable to perform the OK sign. The fingers get pinched, and instead of the tips, the volar surfaces of the thumb and index finger make contact. 

The image below shows a normal OK sign on the right side and an abnormal sign on the left side because of AIN injury:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male complains of difficulty in breathing, swelling of the tongue, and generalized edema of the body following the ingestion of peanuts. The following mediators of inflammation implicated in this case are predominantly produced in the mast cells:
questions.solution:
Platelet-activating factor and leukotrienes are produced in the mast cells.

The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of anaphylactic shock. Anaphylaxis causes mast cell degranulation, vasodilation and secondary facial swelling and desaturation due to laryngeal edema.Mast cells and leukocytes are the sources of prostaglandins ,histamine, platelet-activating factor and leukotrienes. 

Leukotrienes cause an increase in vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation. Prostaglandins mediate pain, fever, and vasodilation.

Histamine is produced in mast cells, basophils, and platelets. It is responsible for vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and endothelial activation.

Related Pearl: Principal Mediators of Inflammation and Their Source

Mediator Source

Prostaglandins Mast cells, leukocytes
Leukotrienes Mast cells, leukocytes
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6) Macrophages, endothelial cells, mast cells
Chemokines Leukocytes, activated macrophages
Platelet-activating factor Leukocytes, mast cells
Complement Plasma (produced in liver)

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: During a vaccination camp, you encounter a plethora of children of various age groups that come for vaccination.  Which of the following vaccines would you be correct to administer via the intramuscular route as per the national immunization schedule of India?
questions.solution:
The Hepatitis B vaccine, Pentavalent vaccine,  along with DPT, Pneumococcal conjugate Vaccine, and the tetanus toxoid are administered via the intramuscular route. 

OPV and Rotaviral vaccines are administered orally whilst BCG & IPV are intradermally administered. The vaccines that are administered subcutaneously are Measles/Rubella vaccine and the JE vaccine.

questions.text: A child who was trying to lift a heavy weight suddenly drops it due to muscle relaxation. Which of the following is true about this reflex?

choices.text: Monosynaptic reflex having Golgi tendon organ as receptor
Disynaptic reflex having Golgi tendon organ as receptor
Monosynaptic reflex having muscle spindle as receptor
Disynaptic reflex having muscle spindle as receptor

questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of an inverse stretch reflex and it is a disynaptic reflex having the Golgi tendon organ as a receptor.

Up to a physiological limit, the harder a muscle is stretched, the stronger the contraction. However, when the tension becomes too great and can cause damage to the muscle fibers, the contraction suddenly stops and the muscle relaxes. This is known as the inverse stretch reflex. 

The receptor for the inverse stretch reflex is the Golgi tendon organ. It lies in series with the muscle fibers and is stimulated by passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle, but mainly the latter. The Golgi tendon organ is innervated by type Ib sensory fibers. These fibers synapse with an inhibitory interneuron which terminates on the motor neuron innervating the same muscle. The inverse stretch reflex is thus disynaptic. Stimulation of the Golgi tendon organ brings about the relaxation of the muscle.

 

Feature Stretch Reflex  Golgi Tendon Reflex 
Receptor Muscle spindle Golgi tendon organ
Afferent fibers Type Ia, Type II Type Ib
Number of synapses Monosynaptic (1 synapse) Disynaptic (2 synapses)
Response Muscle contraction Muscle relaxation
Function Maintains muscle tone, prevents overstretching Prevents excessive force to protect muscle from damage
Example Knee-jerk reflex Dropping a heavy object due to muscle relaxation

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents to the emergency room with fever, headache, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. MRI is done for the patient, which is given below. What is the standard treatment for the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of seizures in a patient with HIV and the MRI showing multiple ring-enhancing lesions suggest a diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin is the standard treatment in this patient. 

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Clinical manifestations include altered mental status, seizures, weakness, cerebellar signs, meningismus, cranial nerve manifestations, etc.

The diagnosis is usually based on the MRI findings of multiple lesions in multiple locations. However, a single lesion may also be present. These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, which show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes, an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring called the eccentric target sign, which is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is usually present.

Differential diagnosis: Other conditions having single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include

  • Primary CNS lymphoma
  • TB, fungal or bacterial abscesses. 

Treatment:

  • Standard treatment is sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 
  • Alternative regimens are clindamycin + pyrimethamine, atovaquone + pyrimethamine, and azithromycin +pyrimethamine + rifabutin.

Prophylaxis:

  • Primary prophylaxis is to prevent the first occurrence of the toxoplasmosis infection, given to patients with IgG antibodies to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double-strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given. The same regimen also offers primary protection against Pneumocystis jirovecii. 
  • Secondary prophylaxis/ maintenance therapy is to prevent the recurrence of toxoplasmosis infection if CD4+ T cell counts are <200/μL. Sulfadiazine/ pyrimethamine and leucovorin are given. Secondary prophylaxis is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months. 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A 29-year-old married woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Her urinary pregnancy test is positive but her ultrasound shows an empty uterus and no gestational sac was found in the adnexa. An ectopic pregnancy is suspected. All of the following  are features in favor of a clinical diagnosis of cervical pregnancy, except _______.

choices.text: Enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
A fully opened internal cervical os
Products of conceptus attached within endocervix

questions.solution:
All the given options are in favor of a clinical diagnosis of cervical pregnancy except fully opened internal cervical os.

A closed internal cervical os is one of the clinical diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy, not an open one.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where implantation occurs in the cervical canal at or below the internal os. Thinning and distension of the cervical canal occur due to erosion of the walls by the trophoblasts. The morbidity and mortality are high due to profuse bleeding.

Rubin's diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy:

  • Uterine bleeding without cramping pain following a period of amenorrhea
  • A soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix
  • A closed internal cervical os
  • A partially opened external cervical os

Ultrasound examination reveals the pregnancy in the cervical canal and an empty uterine cavity.

Management medical and surgical therapy. Methotrexate therapy or feticidal KCl injection may be considered in a few selected cases. Surgery includes a hysterectomy, as it is often required to stop bleeding. Uterine artery embolization with gel foam can also be used to control hemorrhage.

questions.text: The radiologist uses a special inversion recovery sequence known as the FLAIR technique during radiological imaging of the brain. Identify the true statements regarding this technique.
questions.solution:
Fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) is a special inversion recovery sequence with a long inversion time.

The main advantage of FLAIR is that it nullifies the signals of CSF in T2 sequences due to long inversion time and this is very useful in detecting subtle intramedullary lesions.

The primary goal of fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) sequences is to improve contrast in cases where resolution is less important.

The following images show FLAIR, T1, and T2 images in that order.

  • Brain tissue on FLAIR images appears similar to T2 weighted images with grey matter brighter than white matter but CSF is black/dark instead of bright.

  • In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

  • In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense, white matter is dark and grey matter is white. (Water is White on T2, so is CSF)
