questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with progressive swelling of the lower end of the femur. The X-ray findings are given in the below image and a CT scan of the chest reveals osteoblastic metastases. Identify the true statements regarding this condition
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in the given scenario is osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is a primary malignant tumor of the bone, in which the cancerous cells produce osteoid matrix or mineralized bone.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor breaks the cortex and lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The triangular shadow between the cortex and raised ends of the periosteum, known radiographically as the Codman triangle (As shown in the above image).  It is indicative of an aggressive tumor. It is characteristic but not diagnostic of osteosarcoma.

Histologically, Osteosarcoma may be,

  • Telangiectatic or Osteolytic type: It is predominantly a lytic tumor.
  • Osteoblastic
  • Chondroid
  • Fibroblastic

Note: Osteolytic type is more malignant than osteoblastic type.

Surgery is done at the earliest possible time. As the tumor is located in the lower end of femur as suggested by both history and  x-ray, the given patient requires mid-thigh amputation and Hip disarticulation. 

Level of amputation in osteosarcoma:

Site

 Level

Lower end of femur

Mid thigh amputation and  Hip disarticulation

Upper end of femur

Hindquarter amputation and  Hip disarticulation

Upper end of tibia

 Mid thigh amputation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with poor dental hygiene presents to you with complaints of severe pain during swallowing, and difficulty in opening the mouth. He also has a neck swelling, as shown in the image, which he says has been increasing over the past 3 days. O/E there is a woody hard swelling of the floor of the mouth. This condition can occur due to infection in all of the following compartments except _________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ludwig's angina, which occurs due to infection in the Sublingual, Submaxillary, and Submental compartment of Submandibular space (Here Parotid space is not involved).

Ludwig’s Angina is the infection of submandibular space. 

Submandibular space lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of mouth and the tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other side. It is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle:

  • Sublingual compartment (above the mylohyoid).
  • Submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid).

Both compartments freely communicate in the midline with the opposite side. Therefore infection rapidly becomes bilateral.

Dental infections are the most common cause and account for 80% of the cases.

Clinical features:

  • Marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus.
  • When infection is localized to the sublingual space, structures in the floor of the mouth are swollen and tongue seems to be pushed up and back.
  • When the infection spreads to submaxillary space, submental and submandibular regions become swollen, tender and impart woody-hard feel.
  • Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess.
  • The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward threatening the airway.

Treatment:

  • Systemic antibiotics.
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess.
  • Tracheostomy, if there is severe obstruction of airway.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female had undergone a pap smear test whose reports show dysplastic cells in the lower 1/3rd of the cervix. What would be the next step of management in the given scenario?

HPV- Human Papilloma Virus

LLETZ- Large loop excision of the transformation zone
questions.solution:
Dysplastic changes in the lower 1/3rd of cervical tissue are graded as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia I (CIN I).

These mild dysplastic changes are usually after HPV infection, therefore the next step is HPV testing. If that is due to an infection, it is treated and cytology follow-up is done.

Treatment for Dysplasia and CIN: 

1. Mild dysplasia/ LSIL/CIN-1: Is usually due to infection, therefore it is treated and cytology is followed up every 3-6 months. Colposcopy is indicated in:

  • Persistent CIN-I over a year
  • Poor compliance
  • LSIL progressing to HSIL in follow-up

2. Moderate-severe dysplasia/CIN-II- CIN-III: Treatment options are:

  • Local destructive methods: Cryosurgery, fulguration/ electrocoagulation, and laser ablation.
  • Excision of abnormal tissue: Cold-knife conization, laser conization, LLETZ (Large loop excision of the transformation zone), LEEP (Loop electrosurgical excision procedure), and NETZ (Needle excision of the transformation zone).
  • Surgery: Conization, hysterectomy.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: You are performing thyroidectomy in a patient with thyroid neoplasia. Where will you make the Kocher's incision?
questions.solution:
The structures marked as "A" and "B" in the above image are thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage respectively. A Kocher transverse collar incision is typically 3 to 5 cm in length and is placed parallel to a natural skin crease 1 cm below the cricoid cartilage, which is marked as "B".

Rose position is preferred for thyroid surgery. The patient is supine with a towel roll below the shoulder to enable neck extension of 30 degrees. The advantage is a blood-less field as there is decreased venous congestion. However, there is an increased risk of air embolism.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: In women when Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG) decreases because of insulin resistance or androgen excess, the unbound testosterone concentration is increased and leads to hirsutism. This lack of regulation is because

choices.text: Bound testosterone levels is the regulator of reproductive axis not the unbound form.
Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis
Testosterone is a weak stimulator and hence a large variation is required in its levels before eliciting a response.
Unbound Testosterone gets sequestered in adipose tissue.

questions.solution:
Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis.  

The increased unbound testosterone level does not result in an adequate compensatory  feedback  correction because Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis. So, when SHBG decreases because of insulin resistance or androgen excess, the unbound testosterone concentration is increased, potentially leading to hirsutism.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 30-year-old divorced female with schizophrenia has mainly positive symptoms. There were no remissions in 3 years and she also has autistic behavior. Her mother is suffering from depression. Which of the following factors in her suggests a poor prognosis is likely?
questions.solution:
Options 1,4 and 5 are correct.

Prognostic factors of Schizophrenia: 

Good prognostic factors Poor prognostic factors
Acute onset Insidious onset
Late-onset Early-onset
Presence of stressor Absence of a stressor

Good premorbid social, sexual, and work histories

Poor premorbid social, sexual, and work histories
Presence of depression No depression
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Family history of mood disorder Family history of schizophrenia
Married Single, divorced, widowed
 

Withdrawn, autistic behavior
   No remissions in 3 years
  History of Perinatal Trauma

questions.text: A patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia was started on fludarabine. 36 hours after starting the therapy, she developed abdominal pain, hematuria, vomiting, weakness, and paralysis. The consultant suspects tumor lysis syndrome and asks you to order the relevant laboratory investigations. Which among the following would you expect to see in the lab results, considering the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Tumour lysis syndrome where Hyperkalemia, Acidosis, Hyperuricemia, and Hyperphosphatemia can be seen along with Hypocalcemia (not hypercalcemia)

Tumour lysis syndrome is a recognized cause of AKI in patients with cancers. AKI occurs due to uric acid nephropathy and nephrocalcinosis (due to high serum calcium products). It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy. Metabolic abnormalities in tumour lysis syndrome are hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia caused due to the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. Acidosis and acute renal failure may also develop.

During chemotherapy, the treatment kills the malignant cells which lead to increased serum uric acid levels from the turnover of nucleic acids causing Hyperuricemia. This massive destruction of malignant cells may lead to hyperkalemia. Tumour lysis results in the release of intracellular phosphate pools, which causes hyperphosphatemia, this leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium(hypocalcemia). Deposition of calcium phosphate and hyperphosphatemia leads to renal failure.

 Management of TLS includes

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (controversial)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy was admitted with failure to thrive. Lab investigations showed high levels of ammonia and low levels of glucose in the blood. The baby became irritable, lethargic, and stopped feeding followed by onset of seizures. Urine analysis reveals orotic aciduria. Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in a baby boy with neurological symptoms, high ammonia levels in the blood and orotic aciduria is suggestive of hyperammonemia type 2, which occurs due to Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency and is the only urea cycle disorder that is inherited as an X-linked trait.

The clinical features in OTC deficiency are:

  • High glutamine in urine is usually seen in hyperammonemia since it is the transport form of ammonia from the brain and most other tissues.
  • Increased uracil in urine can be seen in OTC deficiency (Hyperammonemia type 2). When OTC is deficient, carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria spills to the cytoplasm then it enters into pyrimidine synthesis.
  • Pyrimidine synthesis will yield intermediates like orotic acid (on oxidation of pyrimidine ring). Increased catabolism of pyrimidine would lead to increased levels of uracil.
  • Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to a high protein diet.

Distinguishing factors of hyperammonemia type 2 are:

  • Orotic aciduria
  • Increased pyrimidine synthesis

 

Note:

All urea cycle disorders are autosomal recessive except hyperammonemia type 2 which is X-linked recessive.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 4-year-old stunted boy presented with fever cough, cold, and conjunctivitis and developed pneumonia after a few days. The characteristic cells of this type of pneumonia are shown in the given slide. This child has____
questions.solution:
Giant cells shown in the image are seen in Hecht's pneumonia, also known as giant cell pneumonia.  It is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition. 

The postmortem examination (autopsy) shows multinucleated giant cells or Warthin–Finkeldey giant cells lining the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs.

Measles (Rubeola) is caused by an RNA paramyxovirus. It spreads via droplets. The incubation period is 8–12 days and the secondary attack rate is ≥90%.

The period of communicability is -3 to +5 days after the appearance of the rash. The prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, and upper respiratory tract infection. The rash appears on 4th day of fever, most common sites are the face and retro auricular area.

Koplik spots and Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic for measles. The most common cause of death is pneumonia.

Other complications are subacute sclerosing panencephalitis, multiple sclerosis, and Crohn's disease.

It is a vaccine preventable infection. The vaccine is live-attenuated (Edmonston–Zagreb) strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age.

questions.text: The operating surgeon after completing a mastectomy procedure puts a drain to prevent serous collections and asks the junior resident to follow up on the case. What would be the usual time gap required for the removal of this drain by the resident?
questions.solution:
Drains put in to drain serous collections ( as mentioned in the above given clinical scenario) usually can be removed after 5 days.

A drain should be removed as soon as it is no longer required because, if left in, it can itself predispose to the fluid collection as a result of tissue reaction.

Principles followed while removing drains,

  • Drains put in to cover perioperative bleeding may usually be removed after 24 hours, e.g. thyroidectomy
  • Drains put in to drain serous collections usually can be removed after 5 days, e.g. mastectomy
  • Drains put in to cover colorectal anastomoses should be removed at about 5–7 days. It is important to note that the drain does not prevent any intestinal leakage, but merely may assist any such leakage to drain externally rather than to produce life-threatening peritonitis.
  • During the removal of a chest drain, the patient should be asked to breathe in and hold their breath, thus doing a Valsalva maneuver. In this way, no air is sucked into the pleural cavity as the tube is removed

questions.text: While conducting a prospective study to know the effect of alcohol on lung cancer, it is noted that smoking is a confounding factor, which may give you false results in the study. Which of the following technique/s can help in reducing the confounding?
questions.solution:
Blinding does not eliminate confounding factors. Blinding is done to eliminate the bias (such as subject bias, observer bias, or investigator bias).
 
A confounding factor is defined as the one associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups.
 
 
For example, a prospective study is being conducted to know the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. However, individuals who drink alcohol are most likely to smoke. So, smoking is associated with exposure. Also, smoking is an independent causative factor for lung cancer. Thus, smoking is a confounding factor.
 
In the above example, if the study is conducted without eliminating the confounding factor, then the result may falsely suggest that alcohol is a causative factor for lung cancer. 
 
Techniques to eliminate confounding factors include
  • Randomization
  • Matching
  • Stratified randomization
  • Restriction
 
Randomization is the random allocation of the participants in experimental studies (Ex.randomized control trial) into the study group and control group.
 
Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (for example, case-control and cohort studies), is the process where the participants in two groups are matched based on factors such as age, gender, race, smoking status, etc. to eliminate the potential confounders.
 
Stratified randomization, which is also known as prestratification or blocking, is the process that combines both randomization and matching techniques. In this method, the participants are first grouped into subgroups which internally match with potential confounding factors such as age, race, gender, etc. An equal number of participants form each subgroup are then allocated to the study and control groups.
 
Restriction: This method restricts the study to only those participants with particular characteristics. For example, a study can be restricted to participants of only one gender, race, age group, geographical area, disease severity, etc., thus eliminating the potential confounders.

questions.text: An unemployed man read an advertisement regarding Clinical trials of a new drug. He was not suffering from any disease but signed up for this study due to dire need of money.  Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the  phase of clinical trial he would have most likely joined?

choices.text: The given phase of clinical trial  is an  open-label study
This phase requires randomisation and blinding
Pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug are observed in this phase
Safety and tolerability of the drug are observed in this phase

questions.solution:
Phase I of Clinical trial constitutes of 10-100 healthy volunteers. It is an open-label study where randomisation and blinding are not required.

The aim is to study the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug.

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

3–5 years

Unending, after drug approval

questions.text: A 26-year-old married woman presented with complaints of difficulty in breast-feeding in the right breast. The appearance of the right breast is shown in the below image. This finding is seen in all of the following conditions except,
questions.solution:
The above image shows a slit-like retraction of the nipple, which is seen in all the given conditions except ductal carcinoma.

A slit-like retraction of the nipple may be caused by duct ectasia, chronic periductal mastitis, and other benign breast conditions like fibroadenoma.

Circumferential retraction of the nipple is suggestive of underlying carcinoma.

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presents with the multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatic distribution. The lesions are limited to the cutaneous tissues. On microscopy from tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia as shown in the image below are seen. Which of the following is the best drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Itraconazole is used in the treatment of cutaneous sporotrichosis.

The presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

  • Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole ,luliconazole
  • Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

Other options:

Amphotericin B and itraconazole are used for the management of extracutaneous sporotrichosis.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including Candida glabrata and Candida krusei), Scedosporium, and Fusarium.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: The following are unipennate muscles:
questions.solution:
Options 2, 3 and 5 are correct. The second lumbrical of the hand, flexor pollicis longus, and plantar interossei are unipennate muscles.

Rectus femoris and second lumbrical of the sole are bipennate muscles.

Examples of unipennate muscles are: 

  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Flexor pollicis longus
  • Palmar interossei
  • 1st and 2nd lumbrical of the palm
  • Peroneus tertius
  • Plantar interossei

Examples of bipennate muscles are:

  • Dorsal interossei
  • Rectus femoris,
  • Flexor hallucis longus,
  • Peroneus longus,

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: You diagnose Retractile testis in a 2-year-old child, who was brought to you with the complaints of multiple episodes of the disappearance of the right testis from the past 1 year. Identify the true statement regarding this condition
questions.solution:
A retractile testis is a normally developed and descended testis that retracts back into the inguinal canal due to hyper reflexive cremasteric muscle contraction.

Therefore any stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and to temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. When the cremaster relaxes, the testis reappears in the scrotum.

The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal (normal rugosity is seen).

Retractile testes require no treatment 

Note: Chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis because both of them describe a condition, wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position. 

Chair Test:  Here, The young patient is asked to sit on a chair hugging his knees to his chest. This maneuver helps the retractile testis to get pushed down back to the bottom of the scrotum. By this test retractile testis can be differentiated from the ectopic testis.

Remember:

Ectopic testis is present outside the usual path of descent from the abdomen to the scrotum. Some of the ectopic sites include the femoral triangle, the root of the penis, and perineum. but a retractile testis is present in the scrotum and occasionally jumps to lie in the inguinal canal. 

An ectopic testis is usually treated with orchidopexy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to you with the complaints of multiple acne over her face. You suspect acne vulgaris and plans to treat her with a chemical peeling technique by using Jessner’s solution.  Which of the following is present in this solution?
questions.solution:
Jessner’s solution contains Lactic acid (14%), Salicylic acid (14%), and Resorcinol (14%)  in ethanol.

It is a clear, faintly amber-colored liquid used for chemical peeling. The depth of the peel is determined by the number of coats applied.

Each component of jessner's solution has specific effects,

  • Salicylic acid removes intracellular lipids and also enhances the penetration of other agents.
  • Resorcinol disrupts the weak hydrogen bonds of keratin.
  • Lactic acid causes corneocyte detachment and subsequent desquamation of stratum corneum.

Note:

Chemical peeling is mainly recommended for facial rejuvenation(i.e for improving skin texture, fine wrinkles) and in the treatment of photodamaged skin, pigmentary dyschromias, and acne vulgaris. They can also be used to treat actinic keratosis, wrinkles, and scars.

Some important chemical peeling agents are:

  • Citric acid
  • Tartaric acid
  • Pyruvic acid
  • Lactic acid
  • Maleic acid
  • Mandelic acid
  • Jessner's solution-lactic acid+salicylic acid+Resorcinol in ethanol

questions.text:
A 20-year-old medical student presented with 6 months of generalized body ache, which increases with stress and does not respond to NSAIDs. She also complains of sleep disturbances and low mood. On examination, there is increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences. Investigations are given below. The most probable diagnosis is:
  • Routine blood and urine- normal
  • ESR- normal
  • anti-CCP- normal
  • Viral markers-  IgG against HbsAg +
  • Chest and pelvic X-ray- normal
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is fibromyalgia.

The examination findings of tender bony prominences and increased pain sensitivity with associated low mood favour the diagnosis of fibromyalgia. Flaring up symptoms during stress and not having pain relief with NSAIDs also support the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is a diagnosis of exclusion. Other possible conditions like anemia, TB, infections like UTI, rheumatoid arthritis, etc. have to be excluded.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is more common in females. Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and other pelvic pain syndromes.

Treatment strategies include physical conditioning, strength training, exercise programs, and cognitive-behavioral strategies

Other options: 

Option A: Normal levels of ESR and anti-CCP antibodies (Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide) exclude the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option B: Ankylosing spondylitis improves with exercise, unlike this case. Moreover, it might show sacroiliitis on the pelvic radiographs and responds well to NSAIDs. 

Option C: Hepatitis B infection is included in the differential diagnosis of fibromyalgia but the presence of IgG against HbsAg points towards vaccination rather than active infection which would show IgM antibodies against various antigens of Hep B.

questions.text: During your internship, you teach a final year student to calculate the APGAR score for a newborn.  Which of the following statements made by him regarding scoring for each parameter is/are correct?
questions.solution:
The presence of active motion in the baby indeed warrants a score of 2 and a baby with a pink body and blue extremities should indeed be given a score of 1.

Other options:

  • A heart rate of 90/min should be assigned a score of 1
  • A baby with a slow, irregular respiratory effort should be assigned a score of 1
  • Coughing or sneezing in response to a catheter in the nostril warrants a score of 2

 

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A child with bilateral cataracts was brought to the ophthalmology department. Systemic examination reveals hearing loss, a congenital heart defect along with the following lesions that have been present since birth. All of the following are the ocular findings associated with this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing blueberry muffin lesions is suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome and microphthalmos is seen in this condition (not megalophthalmos).

Congenital rubella cataract may occur alone or as part of the classical rubella syndrome which consists of:

  • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: You are posted in the Hematology laboratory where you are evaluating the results of a panel of tests, which includes Platelet count, Bleeding time, PT, APTT for patients who presented with bleeding or clotting manifestations. Which of the following results seem correct to you with their respective diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Options 1 and 3 are correct.

  • Normal Platelet count, Prolonged BT, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT is seen in Von - Willebrand disease. Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor(vWF)  in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet mediated hemostasis.
  • Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT are seen in Hemophilia A and B.

Prothrombin Time evaluates the extrinsic pathway.

It measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin) and indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

 

Other options:

  • Increased PT , Increased APTT and increase in fibrin degradation products are seen in Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Prolonged PT, Normal aPTT is seen in factor VII deficiency, mild Vitamin K deficiency, warfarin use.
  • Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Prolonged PT, Prolonged aPTT is seen in deficiencies of common pathway factors (I, II, V, X), liver disease, DIC, direct thrombin inhibitors, direct factor Xa inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

Finding Bleeding disorders Coagulation disorders
Cause

Quantitative/ Qualitative platelet abnormality

 Deficiency of clotting factors
Sex More common in females (commonly autoimmune) More common in males (commonly X-linked)
Family history Rare (except in VWD) Common
Petechiae Characteristic  Rare
Superficial ecchymosis Small and Multiple Large and Solitary
Bleeding from superficial cuts  Profuse Minimal persistent
Hemarthrosis Rare Characteristic (most common-knee)
Deep dissecting hematomas Rare Characteristic (most common-iliopsoas)
Laboratory tests Bleeding time is prolonged PT and/or PTT are prolonged
Most common Inherited: VWD

Inherited: Hemophilia A

Acquired: Hemorrhagic diathesis of liver disease

VWD: von Willebrand disease

PT: Prothrombin time

PTT: Partial thromboplastin time

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the amino acid that would get added in the translation process shown below?

choices.text: It is formed by post-translational modification.
Its deficiency can lead to atherosclerosis and cardiomyopathy
It is coded by a stop codon.
Helps in the function of glutathione peroxidase and deiodinase.

questions.solution:
The image shows a UGA codon with a selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA which would result in the insertion of Selenocysteine. Selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid, is coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. It is formed by co-translational modification. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA.

Selenocysteine is present at the active site of several human enzymes that catalyze redox reactions such as thioredoxin reductase, glutathione peroxidase, and deiodinase.

Impairment in human selenoproteins have been implicated in tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis and are associated with selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease).

Hydroxylysine and hydroxyproline  are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues which are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibres. 

Related Pearl: Start and stop codons

Start codon: AUG - Methionine

Stop codons:

  • UGA- Selenocysteine (21st Amino acid )
  • UAG- Pyrrolysine (22nd Amino acid)
  • UAA

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with confusion and respiratory distress was admitted in the intensive care unit. His arterial blood gas shows, pH: 7.30, HCO3: 16mEq/L, pCO2: 40mmHg, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. Which among the following can be the causes of the given ABG finding?
questions.solution:
The ABG finding show high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). Options 1, 4 and 5 are the causes.

Diagnosis can be arrived by the following steps:

Step 1: The pH being 7.30 is acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 16 mEq/L is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Calculating the Anion gap:

  Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

                   = 145-(100+16)

                   = 29 mEq/L

Which is a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female came with complaints of progressive hearing loss. The audiogram showed a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz and the following type of graph is obtained on Tympanometry. Identify the true statements regarding this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the tympanometry showing As type of graph are suggestive is suggestive of Otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is primarily a disease of the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy, menopause.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal and mobile, unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartz sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC)

In this condition, Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicates that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced.

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with a placement of prosthesis.

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the opd with the complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  Which of the following is true with respect to the stridor seen in this baby?

choices.text: Increases in prone position and subsides on crying
Subsides on prone position and increases with crying
Subsides both on crying and prone position
Increases with both prone position and crying

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of laryngomalacia, as the image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis and the stridor associated with this condition subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying.

Excessively flaccid supraglottic larynx, getting sucked in during inspiration, resulting in stridor is the typical feature of laryngomalacia. It is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. 

Direct laryngoscopy shows elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds, and prominent arytenoids. 

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 9 month-old-child with developmental regression, was brought with repeated epileptic spasms upon arousal. On examination, you notice the presence of shagreen patches. The EEG showed irregular multifocal high-voltage spike and wave activity with a chaotic high-voltage slow background. MRI brain shows subependymal hamartomas. You manage this case by prescribing a first line drug. Which of the following is correct regarding the first-line drug approved for this condition?
questions.solution:
Options 2,4 and 5 are correct.

The given clinical presentation and EEG interpretation referred to as Hypsarrythmia is seen in Infantile spasms (West syndrome) associated with Tuberous sclerosis(2 Major criteria - Shagreen patch and subependymal nodule - are present). Vigabatrin is particularly effective in infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis and is considered as first-line treatment in this condition.

Side effects of Vigabatrin:

  • Concentric visual field constriction is a side-effect of vigabatrin. Bilateral vision loss which develops is progressive and permanent. 
  • Weight gain is also a common side effect.

 

ACTH and glucocorticoids are effective in infantile spasms. ACTH is considered to be drug of choice for infantile spasms that are not associated with tuberous sclerosis

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and consists of a triad of:

  • Infantile spasms (salaam attacks)
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrythmia (abnormal EEG)
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

Other options:

Vigabatrin may harm the developing fetus, and it is classified in pregnancy category C. Other significant associated side effects are fatigue, somnolence (not insomnia), dizziness, hyperactivity, and seizures.

Diagnostic criteria for the tuberous sclerosis complex:

 
Major features  
  • Facial angiofibromas or forehead plaque
  • Non‐traumatic ungual or periungual fibroma
  • Hypomelanotic macules (more than three)
  • Shagreen patch (connective tissue naevus)
  • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
  • Cortical tuber
  • Subependymal nodule
  • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
  • Cardiac rhabdomyoma, single or multiple
  • Lymphangiomyomatosis
  • Renal angiomyolipoma
Minor features 
  • Multiple randomly distributed pits in dental enamel
  • Hamartomatous rectal polyps
  • Bone cysts
  • Cerebral white matter migration lines
  • Gingival fibromas
  • Non‐renal hamartoma
  • Retinal achromic patch
  • Confetti’ skin lesions
  • Multiple renal cysts 
Diagnosis

Definite TSC: either two major features or one major feature with two minor features

Probable TSC: one major feature and one minor feature.

Possible TSC: either one major feature or two or more minor features

questions.text: A child developed severe neutropenia following myelosuppressive chemotherapy and has been prescribed a recombinant human granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). In humans, these colony-stimulating factors (CSFs) such as GM-CSF, and IL-7 are mainly produced from:
questions.solution:
The colony stimulating factors (CSFs) like GM-CSF, and IL-7 are mainly produced from marrow stromal cells, T lymphocytes, macrophages.

Functions of colony-stimulating factors:

  • stimulate hematopoiesis
  • stimulate formation of blood cell colonies from bone marrow progenitors 
  • increase leukocyte numbers during immune and inflammatory responses
  • replace leukocytes that are consumed or destroyed during such responses

questions.text: While performing an autopsy on a burn victim, the following cutaneous findings were noted. What is the term used to describe these burns?
questions.solution:
The term used to describe the burns shown in the image is filigree burn or arborescent burn or Lichtenberg’s flower or feathering. It is a finding in burns due to lightning.

The fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge. It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two. It occurs due to the rupture of small vessels and is seen in a fern-like pattern or the branching of a tree. 

Option B: When the skin is in firm contact with an electrical conductor, splitting of the layers of the epidermis or those of the epidermal-dermal junction. This may in turn produce a raised blister known as a Joule burn.

The image below shows a Joule burn:

 

Option C: When the contact is less firm, an air gap is formed between the skin and the conductor. Thus the current traverses the gap as a spark. This leads to a distinct hard brownish keratin nodule raised above the surrounding surface known as a spark lesion.

Option A: Crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns, where the voltage is in the multi-kilovolt range, sparking may occur over many centimeters. This can cause multiple spark lesions giving rise to a crocodile-skin effect.

The image below shows multiple spark lesions and the inset shows the crocodile skin effect:

 

Image below shows the various electrical marks.

questions.text: A person suffering from fistula-in-ano was managed with the following technique. Which of the following statements is true about this technique?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Seton's technique. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain.

Seton’s technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. It is left in place for 3 months and if there is evidence of good healing it is removed.

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those which are distal to the dentate line, loosely placement of seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

This may be converted to a cutting seton by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helps in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the  continuity of the sphincter.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with chronic breathlessness on exertion. His blood pressure was 100/60mm Hg and examination on the neck showed the following neck finding during inspiration. Your list of the differential diagnosis for this sign will include:
questions.solution:
Options 2, 3, and 4 are correct.

The shown sign is the Kussmaul sign, it is a paradoxical rise or a lack of fall in JVP with inspiration. Kussmaul's sign is not seen in cardiac tamponade or Cor Pulmonale. 

Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure and increased intrathoracic volume, the capacity of the right heart increases and the JVP falls. In conditions where the myocardium or pericardium is poorly compliant, it does not allow the right heart chambers to accommodate more blood and this fall is not seen. In fact, due to an increase in venous return during inspiration, the JVP might rise. This is called Kussmaul's sign.

This is seen in

  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarcts
  • Advanced cases of left ventricular systolic failure

Kussmaul’s sign is not seen in patients with cardiac tamponade because even though the increase in pericardial pressure exerts an inward force compressing the entire heart during inspiration, the increase in negative intrathoracic pressure is still transmitted to the right side of the heart. This allows for an increase in blood flow to the right atrium. Therefore, the JVP falls as seen in normal conditions.

Feature  Cardiac tamponade Constrictive pericarditis Restrictive cardiomyopathy
 Pulsus paradoxus +++ + +/- (Rare)

JVP

Prominent x descent 		 +++ + +++
JVP
Prominent y descent		 - ++ +

JVP Kussmaul's sign

 -  +++ +/- (Rare)
Pericardial knock - ++ -
Third heart sound - - +
Electrical alternans in ECG ++ - -
Low Voltage ECG ++ ++ +

questions.text: Drugs targeting subtypes of human phosphodiesterase enzyme have had a profound impact on management of various medical conditions. Which of the following drugs and their clinical application are correctly matched with the enzyme they act upon?
questions.solution:
Options 2,3 and 4 are correctly matched.

Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor that is indicated for peripheral vascular disease. It promotes the accumulation of intracellular cAMP.

  • It is contraindicated in patients with heart failure.
  • Has been reported to increase non-sustained ventricular tachycardia
  • Headache is the most common side effect

Milrinone acts by inhibition of the enzyme phosphodiesterase-3 (PDE 3).

The PDE-3 inhibitors decrease cellular cAMP degradation, resulting in increased levels of cAMP. This results in positive ionotropic and chronotropic action of the heart. It also dilates veins and arteries thereby decreasing preload and afterload.

Erectile dysfunction is treated by Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors like Sildenafil, Vardenafil, Tadalafil, and a side effect of these is bluish vision.

Other options: 

Roflumilast is an oral PDE4 inhibitor, which has been approved for patients with COPD with severe disease (FEV1 < 50% predicted), frequent exacerbations, and chronic bronchitis.

questions.text: The structure marked in red gets its nerve supply from?
questions.solution:
The muscle shown in the image is piriformis and is supplied by branches from S1, S2.

 The piriformis muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It is inserted into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibres or above the muscle.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle.

Other Options:

Superior gluteal nerve: Gluteus medius/minimus

The femoral nerve: Quadriceps femoris and many more.

The Sciatic nerve: Biceps femoris and many more

The following image shows different muscles and of the pelvis and their attachments

questions.text: During a labor posting, you happen to witness the management of a patient with shoulder dystocia for which the senior resident performs the maneuver shown in the image below. The maneuver is ____.
questions.solution:
The image depicts rotation of the posterior shoulder to 180º in a corkscrew manner, this is Woods corkscrew maneuver for shoulder dystocia.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, postdatism, and prior history, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.

Turtle Sign is positive: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. The baby's cheeks bulge out, resembling a turtle pulling its head back into its shell. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

Mc.Roberts maneuver - flexion and abduction of the thigh

Woods corkscrew maneuver - rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion

Zavanelli maneuver - push the head back and do cesarean

Cleidotomy - fracture clavicle of the baby

Symphysiotomy - divide pubic symphysis of the mother

Other manoeuvres: Rubin, Gaskin (All Four's Position), Hubbard, Barnum maneuver.

Note:

  • In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manouvre.
  • Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

The above-given image illustrates Mc.Roberts maneuver.

The image above illustrates cleidotomy being performed

questions.text: In a lecture slide prepared by your friend for a zoom seminar on Protein synthesis, you see the following points. You would make a correction to:

choices.text: Eukaryotic mRNAs have 7-methylguanosine caps at 5' end.
The poly(A) tail protects the 3′ end of mRNA from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease attack
Shine-Dalgarno sequence helps to initiate translation in mammalian cells

questions.solution:
Shine-Dalgarno sequence helps initiate translation in prokaryotes.  In Mammalian cells the Kozak consensus sequence functions as the translation initiation site.

Eukaryotic mRNAs have poly-A tails at 3' end and 7-methylguanosine caps at 5' end. Eukaryotic messenger RNA usually undergoes post-transcriptional modification and polyadenylation is an important part of this post-transcriptional modification. They help to stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened. 

The poly(A) tail protects the 3′ end of mRNA from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease attack and facilitates translation.

The attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the guanyl cap at the 5' end. It also prevents the attack of 5′→ 3′ exonucleases

questions.text: Below are the Darrow-Yannet diagrams used to study the fluid distribution in different body compartments. The dashed lines indicate the possible change. Which of the following changes will be seen if hypertonic and hypotonic saline respectively are added to ECF? (A represents the normal state)
questions.solution:
On the addition of hypertonic and hypotonic saline, Darrow-Yannet diagram D and C will be obtained respectively.

Water can diffuse from ECF to ICF and vice -versa, whilst almost all of the added sodium chloride (from saline) stays in ECF. The osmolality of ICF and ECF are almost equal, any change in either causes the fluid shift, to equilibrate the osmolality.

The addition of hypertonic saline- increases the osmolality of ECF, water shifts from ICF to ECF to balance the osmolality- causes contraction of ICF and expansion of ECF.

Addition of hypotonic saline- ECF becomes a little diluted (osmolality decreases), excess water shifts from ECF to ICF. As a result, overall osmolality of ECF and ICF decreases, and the expansion of both ICF and ECF.

HypErtonic saline - ECF Expansion

HypOtonic saline- bOth ECF/ICF expansion

 

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: The following procedure is planned for a pregnant woman at 37-weeks of gestation with a breech presentation. The presence of which of the following conditions will be considered as contraindications for this procedure:
questions.solution:
The given procedure is an external cephalic version. Options 2 and 5 are contraindications for it.

Obesity and the rupture of membranes are contraindications of ECV. Transverse lie is an indication.

Factors which increase the success rate of the procedure include multiparity, unengaged presenting part, nonanterior placenta, nonobese patient, and abundant amni­onic fluid.

Prerequisites for ECV:

  • More than 37 weeks
  • Liquor should be adequate
  • The membranes should be intact
  • No C/I for vaginal delivery
  • Single fetal pregnancy

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: During a Biochemistry lecture on enzyme kinetics, the tutor shows the following graph. This graph illustrates:

choices.text: Lineweaver Burk Plot of  Noncompetitive inhibition
Lineweaver Burk Plot of competitive inhibition

questions.solution:
The graph shows a plot of 1/V(Reaction Velocity) vs Concentration of inhibitor across various concentrations of substrate. Hence is a Dixon Plot. The intercept on the x-axis gives Ki which is suggestive of noncompetitive inhibition.

Lineweaver Burk Plot is 1/V vs 1/Substrate concentration.

questions.text: An international traveler wants to get vaccinated against typhoid. Which of the following is true when concerning the safety of the Ty21a vaccine?

choices.text: It can be given simultaneously with other live vaccines
It can be given to patients taking anti-bacterial drugs
It is efficacious in patients having acute diarrhoea
It can be given safely to HIV patients with CD4 <200 as long as they are asymptomatic

questions.solution:
Other live vaccines can be given simultaneously with the Ty21a typhoid vaccine. 

Ty21a is a live-attenuated oral vaccine for individuals ≥5 years of age.

  • The regimen is 1st, 3rd, and 5th day - 3 doses.
  • Repeat every 3 years for endemic areas, and every year for traveling individuals. 

Not recommended in:

  • Patients on antimitotic drugs and immunosuppressants
  • Acute febrile illness
  • Acute intestinal infestation
  • Congenital or acquired immunodeficiency

Ty21a vaccine can be administered in an HIV-positive asymptomatic patient as long as the CD4+ count is >200/ cubic mm. 

Proguanil and antibacterial drugs should be stopped from 3 days before to 3 days after the vaccine. 

The vaccine is unlikely to be effective if it is administered at the time of ongoing diarrhea.

Other available vaccines against typhoid include:

  • Inactivated whole cell vaccine
  • Injectable Vi polysaccharide vaccine
  • Vi-rEPA vaccine

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with Kearns-Sayre syndrome. Which of his relatives could be affected by the same disease?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern of Kearns-Sayre syndrome is mitochondrial inheritance, therefore his sister could be affected with the disease.

As the disease is only transmitted from mother to all offsprings, he neither could transmit the disease to his offsprings, be it male or female child nor could he have got it from his father.

Kaern-Sayre syndrome :

  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Pigmentory retinopathy
  • Cardiomyopathy

Mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome.
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.
  • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.

Related Pearl: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother
  • These diseases include: (mnemonic: KLMNOP)

questions.text: An infant was brought to you with the complaints of projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, you were able to palpate a firm ovoid mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant. A diagnosis of  Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis was made. Which of the following type of metabolic abnormality is seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Hypochloremia with paradoxical aciduria is seen in patients diagnosed with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting between 2 and 8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks.

  • Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk.
  • Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting.
  • Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.

Metabolic abnormality:

  • Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the OPD. His parents describe that the boy had an episode of abnormal jerking movements that started in his left hand and gradually involved the entire arm. Following this, the patient experienced weakness and difficulty in moving the left arm for about an hour. Two similar episodes have also occurred in the past. His father is a known case of epilepsy. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the first-line drug used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes Jacksonian march followed by Todd’s palsy. These are characteristics of a focal seizure. Among the given drugs, the first-line drug for focal seizures is carbamazepine which is a Sodium-channel blocker.

First-line agents in the treatment of focal seizures:

  • Lamotrigine
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Levetiracetam

Carbamazepine is most effective in complex partial seizures. It is also used in GTCS and simple partial seizures, trigeminal and related neuralgias, manic depressive psychosis.

Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause leukopenia, aplastic anemia, or hepato-toxicity and hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.text: A multiparous woman is bleeding profusely after the delivery of the placenta. She continues to bleed even after attempts of uterine massage and administration of uterotonic agents. Her uterus feels soft and boggy. So, you decide to proceed with the technique shown in the image. Which of the following statements are true about it?
questions.solution:
The given image is Bakri balloon tamponade, options 1, 2, 3, and 4 are true about it.

A Bakri Postpartum Balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity and stop bleeding. It treats refractory uterine atony.

The insertion process requires two or three team members. First-person to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure. Another to place the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilize it. The third person instills normal saline to inflate the balloon, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL followed by further instillation over a few minutes for a total of 300 to 500 mL to arrest hemorrhage. Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter is generally removed after 12 to 24 hours.

Segstaken­ Blakemore, Rusch, and ebb balloons, Foley's catheter, and condom catheters can also be used instead.

In the technique where Foley's catheter is utilized, a 24F-30F size of the catheter with 30ml balloon is used, the tip is guided into the uterine cavity and filled with 60-80ml of saline. In some cases, if the balloon ruptures, a 34F with 60ml balloon can be used. Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter can be removed after 12 -24 hours.

questions.text: An orthopedic resident prescribes pain relievers for a patient diagnosed with Kohler's disease. Which of the following bones is usually affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Osteochondrosis and osteochondritis are conditions in which a small segment of articular bone or cartilage is demarcated or separated and necrosed. The affected part shows features of ischemic necrosis. This is widely seen in adolescents and young adults, with trauma and repetitive stress being the common causes. An example of this disorder is osteochondritis dissecans.

Commonly affected sites are slightly bulbous areas with convex articular surfaces: 

  • Inner (medial) surface of the medial femoral condyle in the knee
  • Anteromedial corner of the talus in the ankle
  • Superomedial part of the femoral head
  • Humeral capitulum
  • Head of the second metatarsal bone

Clinically, they present with intermittent pain over the mid-foot, which may be accompanied by swelling and a small effusion in the joint. It typically resolves over the years, as the child grows up.

X-ray imaging, MRI, and radionuclide scanning with 99mTc-HDP are the imaging modalities used for diagnosis.

Treatment includes symptomatic treatment of pain. Special supportive shoes may also be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Osteochondritis of the lunate is known as Kienbock's disease.

Option B: Osteochondritis of the capitulum is known as Panner's disease.

Option D: Osteochondritis of the calcaneum is known as Sever's disease.

Related Pearl: Osteochondritis

Osteochondritis Bones affected
Kienbock Lunate
Scheuermann Ring epiphysis of the vertebra
Perthes Proximal femoral epiphysis  
Osgood-Schlatter Tibial tuberosity
Sever Calcaneum
Kohler Navicular bone
Freiberg

Second

(or 3rd,4th,5th)metatarsal head 
Iselin  Fifth metatarsal base

questions.text: A newborn with persistent cyanosis was evaluated. He was found to have a congenital heart disease that is schematically represented below. What is the most likely embryological defect causing this?

choices.text: Failure in formation of conotruncal ridges

questions.solution:
The given image shows persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) and the embryological defect causing this is a failure in the formation of the conotruncal ridges.

This leads to the absence of a conotruncal or aorticopulmonary septum which normally divides the outflow tract into the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.

Deoxygenated blood goes into the right heart and back into systemic circulation via the aorta. Oxygenated blood goes into the left heart and then back into pulmonary circulation via the pulmonary artery. This parallel circulation gives rise to persistent cyanosis as seen in this patient. 

Since the conotruncal ridges also participate in the formation of the interventricular septum, an accompanying ventricular septal defect (VSD) may also be seen. The persistent truncus overrides both the ventricles and receives mixed blood from both sides. 

 

Other options -

Option A - Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum leads to the transposition of the great arteries (TGA). This leads to the aorta originating from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

 

Option B - Anterior displacement of the conotruncal septum gives rise to the Tetralogy of Fallot. It is characterized by 4 cardinal features - pulmonary infundibular stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is represented by the schematic image given below. 

 

Option D - Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection causes the drainage of oxygenated blood (brought in by pulmonary veins) into the systemic venous circulation. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male from a suburban area presented with fever and rash, involving the palms and soles. He gives a history of bite by an organism that looks like the one seen in the image below. His vitals are stable and there is no eschar formation at the site of the bite. Which of the following can be a likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hard tick and a history of characteristic rash present on palms and soles after a tick bite and no eschar is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever due to  Rickettsia rickettsii infection.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever presents with fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia as the most common symptoms during the first 3 days. Rash is evident in only 14% of patients on the first day of illness, which is present on palms and soles.

The most common serologic test for confirmation of the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. It is administered orally at 100 mg twice daily.

Rash on palms and soles is typically described in the following 3 diseases:

  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Hand Foot and Mouth Disease.

 The image shows a hard tick that can transmit-

  • Tick typhus (Rickettsia conorii)
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Kyasanur forest disease
  • Tularemia
  • Human babesiosis(Babesia microti)
  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Rickettsia rickettsii).

Identification of the tick alone helps rule out the other options as Rickettsia prowazekii is louse-borne, Rickettsia typhi is flea-borne and Rickettsia tsutsugamushi is mite-borne. 

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

Related Pearl: Human diseases caused by the Rickettsia and Orientia species
