questions.text: A person was brought to the hospital after he consumed a poisonous plant confusing it with parsley, a harmless herb. Relatives bring the plant with them which appears as shown below. The patient has developed burning in mouth and throat, mental confusion and progressive paralysis. On examination, a slow pulse is felt and his breath has a mousy odour.  Which among the following is correct about this plant?
questions.solution:
The given plant is hemlock, options 1,3, 4 and 5 are true about it.

The Greek philosopher, Socrates was executed with the poison hemlock/Socratic poison(Conium maculatum), also called as spotted hemlock, as it has purple spots on the stem. Death from Conium maculatum occurs due to overstimulation of nicotinic receptors, it is a peripheral nerve poison. Toxic compounds are alkaloids coniine and methyl coniine. Ingestion/inhalation/injection can lead to poisoning as coniine is a volatile alkaloid.

All parts of poison hemlock contain coniine and similar alkaloids that are structurally and functionally analogous to nicotine.

Clinical features include slow pulse, breath has a mousy odour, burning in mouth and throat, mental confusion and progressive paralysis, Overstimulation of nicotine receptors can rapidly progress from seemingly mild symptoms to death from respiratory failure. Death is due to respiratory paralysis, post portem changes are those of asphyxia.

Typically, ingestion of poison hemlock is due to misidentification because of its similarity in appearance to wild carrot. 

Related Pearl: Common names for plant poisons

Plant poison Common name
Conium maculatum Poison hemlock
Digitalis purpurea Foxglove
Nerium odorum White oleander
Ricinus communis Castor bean
Abrus precatorius Rosary pea
Aconite Monk's hood
Atropa belladona Deadly nightshade

questions.text: On neurologic examination, a patient is not able to recognize the key kept in his hand with his eyes closed. But, immediately recognizes the object once he sees it. Which lobe of the brain is likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of astereognosis. It is seen in lesions involving the superior parietal lobe which is marked as '3' in the given image.

Stereognosis is the ability to identify an object by a perception of the form and nature of an object without looking at it. This ability depends on intact touch, pressure, and proprioceptive impulses. The loss of integration of sensory impulses is called astereognosis. Astereognosis is seen in lesions of the superior parietal lobule and dorsal column pathways.

There are two parietal lobes, the dominant side, and the non-dominant side:

  • The functions of the dominant side of the parietal lobe are calculation, language, planned movement, appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia.
  • The function of the non-dominant side is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia.

The lesions in the posterior parietal lobe lead to loss of hand-eye coordination. Because neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

Image below shows the marked area as 1,2,3 and 4

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was rescued from a neglected household. The girl was in severe malnutrition and was therefore fed high-calorie meals at the rehabilitation home. She developed confusion and seizures. Investigations revealed that her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels were low. These electrolyte abnormalities are due to excessive administration of ____.
questions.solution:
The child in this case is suffering from refeeding syndrome, and her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels are low due to the increased serum insulin levels, which in turn is caused due to the excessive administration of carbohydrates.

The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia after the cellular uptake of phosphate during the 1st week of starting refeeding.

Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral alimentation. 

When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels may produce the following:

  • Hypophosphatemia (hallmark)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Hypophosphatemia can produce the following manifestations:

  • Cardiac: Hypotension, Decreased stroke volume
  • Respiratory: Impaired diaphragm contractility, Dyspnea, Respiratory failure
  • Neurologic: Paresthesia, Weakness, Confusion, Disorientation, Lethargy, Areflexic paralysis, Seizures, Coma
  • Hematologic: Leukocyte dysfunction, Hemolysis, Thrombocytopenia

A controlled transition over 3 days is recommended by the WHO for treating malnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: An anatomy professor marks the given point on the bone specimen shown below and questions you regarding the anastomosis which takes place there. All of the following arteries form the anastomosis at the marked area except?
questions.solution:
The depressed area seen on the medial surface of the greater trochanter is called the trochanteric fossa. Trochanteric anastomosis lies near the trochanteric fossa of the femur. The first perforating artery does not contribute to the formation of the Trochanteric anastomosis.

Trochanteric anastomosis:

It lies near the trochanteric fossa of the femur and is formed by,

  • Ascending branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery 
  • Ascending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery
  • Descending branches of the superior and inferior gluteal arteries

Cruciate anastomosis: 

It lies at the level of the lesser trochanter and is formed by:

  • Transverse branches of medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery
  • Ascending branch of the first perforating artery

questions.text: As an anesthetist, You were asked to induce a 5-year-old child who was undergoing surgery for strabismus correction. After conjunctival incision as the surgeon grasps the rectus muscle, you notice the following finding in the cardiac monitor. Which of the following steps can be included in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The cardiac monitor is showing bradycardia, when the surgeon grasps the rectus muscle. This is due to Oculocardiac reflex. All the given 5 options can be included in the management of this condition.

The Oculocardiac reflex is a trigemino-vagal-reflex (afferent through trigeminal nerve, efferent through vagus nerve)

It is most common in pediatrics undergoing strabismus surgery.

Caused by traction on extraocular muscles or pressure on the eyeball

  • Strabismus surgery
  • Cataract surgery
  • Enucleation
  • Retinal detachment surgery
  • Orbital hematoma
  • Ocular trauma

The manifestation can range from bradycardia (most common) to sinus arrest and ventricular ectopic to ventricular fibrillation.

Management includes,

  • Immediately notifying the surgeon and ask for temporary cessation of surgery, until heart rate increases
  • Providing adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anesthesia
  • Administration of IV atropine 10mcg/kg and mild chest compressions can also be done to allow the atropine to circulate

Note: In recalcitrant episodes, A local anesthetic can be injected into the rectus muscles.

Related Pearl: Oculocardiac Reflex

Traction on the extraocular muscles or pressure on the globe causes bradycardia, atrioventricular block, ventricular ectopy, or asystole.

In particular, it is seen with traction on the medial rectus muscle, but it can occur with stimulation of any of the orbital contents, including the periosteum.

Reflex arc involves-

  • Afferent: Orbital contents to ciliary ganglion to ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the sensory nucleus of trigeminal
  • Efferent: Vagus nerve to the heart.

Procedures evoking the reflex-

  • Strabismus surgery in the paediatric age (most common) 
  • Cataract extraction
  • Enucleation
  • Retinal detachment repair.

Management-

  • Temporary cessation of surgical stimulation until heart rate increases
  • Adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anaesthesia
  • IV atropine (10 mcg/kg) if bradycardia persists
  • In recalcitrant episodes, local anaesthetic infiltration of the rectus muscles.

Pretreatment with intravenous atropine or glycopyrrolate can be effective in preventing this condition.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male from the Zaire region in Africa developed high-grade fever, sore throat and pain in the muscles and joints. This was followed by severe vomiting, hemoptysis, and diarrhoea. He develops a maculopapular rash after 5 days. The likely infectious agent is shown in the given image. Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
Options 2,4 and 5 are correct.

The given clinical scenario and the electron micrograph image point towards an infection caused by the Ebola virus.

Ebola virus is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa. It belongs to the Filoviridae family.

Fruit bats act as reservoir hosts of the virus and it is transmitted to humans only accidentally. Human to human transmission is through direct contact with blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person. It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.

Ebola virus is highly virulent and requires maximum containment facilities (Biosafety Level 4) for laboratory work.

Ebola virus shows a bowl of spaghetti appearance.

The infection is common in Sudan and Zaire provinces in Africa. The incubation period of the disease is 2 to 21 days. Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive.

This virus has the highest mortality rate (25–90%) of all the viral hemorrhagic fevers. Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after a complete cure.

questions.text: Which of the following images correctly represent the regulation of the most abundant anterior pituitary hormone?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH), produced by the acidophil cells of the anterior pituitary is the most abundant hormone of the pituitary, and Option C represents the correct regulation of growth hormone secretion.

The following inferences can be made out from the image given as option C.

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone secreted from the hypothalamus acts on the anterior pituitary to release growth hormone.
  • The released growth hormone increases the circulating levels of IGF -1 which exerts its effect on the tissues.
  • Ghrelin promotes the secretion of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary.
  • Somatostatin secreted from the hypothalamus is an inhibitory effect on the GH secretion from the anterior pituitary.
  • Similarly, IGF -1 exerts negative feedback on GH secretion and positive feedback on somatostatin secretion, which in turn inhibits GH secretion.

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary
